reviewText:
I ordered Showtime years ago so I could watch Stargate. And once they sold it to Sci-Fi Channel, I wondered if I should cancel Showtime and save some money. When Dead Like Me came out, I was damn happy I hadn't. If there was anything I would have changed with the first season, it would have been more episodes.
Dead Like Me is one of those shows that's well writen, well acted, funny, irreverant, thought provoking, and just a rollicking good time. MGM and Showtime have a another hit on their hands. I hope they keep up the good work and I can't wait for season two.

well im not reviewing the dvd itself as much as the first season. this is probablly the best new show ive seen in a llllllloooooooooooonnnnnnnnnnngggggggggggg time!!! im glad to see it was recognized and will be returning. anyway back to the season. its smart funny and all around good. i think youll especially like it if you like shows such as buffy the vampire slayer and angel. i hope you give it a shot because its well worth the money

July 2007 Update!!!!!!  There is going to be a movie!  Shooting has either wrapped up or is close to wrapping up.  Star Ellen Muth goes so far as to hint that that a renewal of the series might be possible.  Details are still forthcoming and apart from the movie (and I'm sorry, I don't know if this is a TV, a direct-to-DVD, or theatrical release) nothing definite is known about the chances of the series being revived, but this is definitely good news.  There is some recasting.  Mandy Patinkin, unfortunately, will not be back as Rube nor will Laura Harris as Daisy.  It appears Rube's character is being replaced by a new head reaper, while a new actress will be playing Daisy.  Otherwise all the other actors will be back.  The rest of my review now appears as it was first written back in February 2004.

I would place DEAD LIKE ME on the shortest of short lists of the truly great television shows of the past decade and a half (that date referring to the debut of TWIN PEAKS and a more artistically serious form of television).  Most television shows are unambitious affairs, either because of constraints from the networks or lack of creative talent at the top, but DEAD LIKE ME stands head and shoulders above the competition.  It is not nearly as well as it deserves, primarily because it was a series that appeared on Showtime, which limited its exposure.

The television show begins--we learn later--with a toilet seat from the MIR space station rushing to fulfill its destiny on planet earth, namely to ignite into a ball of fire and strike eighteen-year-old Georgia "George" Lass, who is taking her lunch break on the first day of her temp assignment with the Happy Times Employment Agency.  George looks up at the descending ball, inaudibly utters the word "sh#t" and immediately enters the next stage of her existence, if not her life.  Much to her astonishment, she finds herself standing a few feet away from her body, able to see the living, but herself unseen by all except for a few Grim Reapers, whose job it is to see her into her afterlife.  Usually this involves aiding them to the place where they will spend eternity, but in George's case, she is recruited very much against her will to become a Grim Reaper.  The rest of the first season deals with George's deep resistance to accepting her new vocation, as well as coming to terms with her death, the loss of her family and the discovery of what they unexpectedly meant to her, her need to find a living (it turns out being a Reaper is an unpaid position), her yearning for friends and companionship, and her growing awareness of what it means to be a human being.

The show succeeds on virtually every level.  The scripts are consistently superb, many of them by series creator and STAR TREK: VOYAGER alum Bryan Fuller.  The production values are far beyond the normal television series.  The special effects (and there are more than one would expect on a show of this kind) are always striking.  The photography is simply unmatched in television.  I might be inclined to defend the statement that this is the show has the best photography in the history of television.  The camerawork is difficult to praise too highly, with innovative camera angles, zooms, wide angle lenses, and especially filters to make this an incredibly beautiful show to look at.  It was filmed in Vancouver, but it was supposed to be Seattle, but instead of the rain that one anticipates from the climate, there is constant and brilliant sunshine.  Green dominates the screen (the color of growing things?) in every exterior shot.  It is exhilarating to view a series that is made this well.

The cast is exquisite.  Ellen Muth plays George, and I'm not sure they could have gotten anyone more perfect to play the role.  She is a perfect blend of sullen, grumpy, vulnerable, and lost, and she manages perfectly to communicate her awakening to life by having died.  She is also one of the more interesting actresses to have appeared in sometime, giving the appearance of being average in appearance while in fact being a striking beauty.  Her undead supervisor Rube is played by the great Mandy Patinkin, and he turns in his usual exquisite performance.  Rebecca Gayheart (who was the original Inara on FIREFLY, but left before the pilot was shot) was superb in the first few episodes as Betty, who was replaced in the team by Laura Harris (of "24") as deceased Hollywood bit player and promiscuous party girl Daisy Adair (who continually regales the group with tales of her sexual conquests of movie stars).  Perhaps my favorite moment of the season occurs when the Reapers are forced to catalog and record all the last thoughts of those whose souls they have reaped, and we inadvertently learn Daisy's last thought.  She immediately moves from being an unsympathetic character to one that we love more than a little.  The hard-as-nails Roxy, who works as a meter maid, is played convincingly by Jasmine Guy (of A DIFFERENT WORLD, and the team is rounded out by Callum Blue as the hapless British thief and druggie Mason.  Cynthia Stevenson is great as George's mom.  Special mention has to be made of the supporting character who provides perhaps more hysterical moments during the season than any other, Christine Willes, who plays the unforgettable Dolores Herbig "Brown Eyes," George's supervisor at Happy Times, sometimes friend, and host of her own website called "Getting Things Done," on which she is seen whenever she is home "getting things done."

After loving the first season of the show, I was tremendously excited about two things:  1) the DVD set coming out and 2) the second season.  I was ecstatic when the show was renewed for a second season.  Despite its quality, Showtime has not worked at developing original series as has its rival HBO.  But last fall they announced the show had been renewed for 2004.  The new episodes should begin appearing in May 2004.  I heartily urge anyone who loves great TV like BUFFY THE VAMPIRE SLAYER, SIX FEET UNDER, and FIREFLY to give this remarkable series a shot.  You won't be disappointed.

I love the series and having the dvd is great!!!  I ordered it and can't wait to get it.  If your haven't heard of dead like me and love comedy this is for you!  Dead like me is very funny and well worth the price!  Heck id pay 100 dollers for it!!!

Meet George.  Your typical 18 year-old recent High School Graduate that doesn't know what she wants to do with her life, but knows that College isn't part of it.  So after her mothers persistance she takes a job as a file clerk, only to die on her first day by having a toliet seat from out-space hit her on the head.
When George Wakes up she finds out that fate has chosen her as a Grim-Reaper.  She must help people to the afterlife, until her time comes to go on herself.  It might take 2 weeks, it might take 200 years to get to whereever she's suppose to go, but shes doing a job that she has to do.
Over the course of the first season George meets many very interesting "Grim Reapers" including: Mason, your typical out-for-a-buck reaper, Betty the fashionable reaper, Daisy the once movie "star" that blew everybody from John Wayne to Luke Perry, and Rube the leader of the pack.
The Story also follows the effects of George's death on her family, that she thought never liked her only to realize that she was the backbone that held them together.
Now collected for the first time is the complete first season of the showtime series.  This is a great series, and desearves to be seen by everyone that likes the bizarre, yet comedic that don't have showtime.  Or for fans that want to watch this great season again.
Highly Recomened.

The first season of Showtime's very popular series, Dead Like Me follows George from her death, by the re-entry of a toilet seat off of MIR, through her transformation into a reaper.
One of the best parts of the series is all the ways they find to "off" the people who die in the show, from a canoe flying off a car, toilet seat burning up on re-entry and nailing them in the town square or a dead guy falling off a balcony and landing on a newly-wed couple, it's always different and darkly humorous.
All is not fun and games, as George is also trying to find herself, being a typical "Gen X Slacker", her life really didn't start until she died.
Reeper Sitcom, Addicting show.

Best show ever on tv.  I became a fan, discovered it, only after it was already off the air. I LOVE IT.  it is so original. It's difficult to sit through the first episode, I gave up on the series. It's squarely in the head thoughts of a complete loser that makes everyone else's lives miserable, and full of judgment and laziness to fill the constant stream of thought. I suppose it's a 'realistic' look at the way the world is, in an entitled main character cares about nothing. I'm sure there's growth potential for this character, but I just kept waiting for the promised death by toilet, when I realized that she would probably linger on like this for at least one more episode. Most likely more. And I didn't want to deal with another second. Pass.

Love this show!  This is my second time viewing the series and it is an all time favorite.  The witty, dry humor lands a lot of hits in my mind and sends my thoughts to the deeper recesses where the serious issues reside.  For such a serious topic, it pokes fun at us in a way that doesn't diminish or judge our value.  I don't know if there has ever been a series I can say this about!  I just love it!  Wouldn't another 2 seasons be a treat?

The trials and tribulations of a newly appointed grim reaper named George, an 18-year-old girl recently killed by falling space debris  specifically a space station toilet seat.  George, as a new grim reaper, must navigate life along with her co-workers (both living, dead and undead) and the family she left behind.  Sprinkled with sarcasm, a little profanity, and great insights into the human condition, Dead Like Me is a comical reminder there are lessons to be learned in life; no matter if you're living, recently departed, or tasked with being a grim reaper.
LOVE it!!!!

Smart, funny, and poignant.  This is one of my favorite TV series, and sadly, it was canceled before its time (see Firefly).  It has an ensemble cast, with standout performances by Ellen Muth, Mandy Patinkin, Callum Blue, Cynthia Stevenson, and Jasmine Guy.  Supporting actors are standouts as well.  I think what I truly like best about this program, is the evolution of Ellen Muth's character, Georgia Lass.  Great programs aren't just about what happens, but what happens to the people involved.  Truly, great TV, and something I've watched multiple times.

How can grim reapers be charming? How can anyone laugh at death? What the heck are gravelings? Watch this quirky, humorous, sometimes touching series to find out. Light viewing with a wisp of philosophy and several prat falls, including one involving a banana peel. Try it---you'll like it.

This short-lived Showtime comedy garnered high ratings on IMDB so I decided to watch it.  I was disappointed.  While the concept of ordinary-looking grim reapers walking among us is clever, it failed to execute.  It is marketed as a comedy, but it is not funny enough to warrant that label and it also fails as a drama.  That puts it, unwittingly, in the dreaded comedy-drama or "dramedy" category.  This middling show lived short for a reason.  It is just not that good.

You might think, because of the young cast, this is suitable for teens.  It's not.  Even though there is no nudity, the phrases "$10 blow job" and "hard nipples" are bandied about as if they are nothing.  The same is true of the profanity (taking Jesus' Name to be nothing more than a trivial exclamation).

I am shocked to see the high reviews.  Putting the language and coarse material aside, it was not really funny; it did not provide any insight into death or suffering (although it tried to insert a thought now and again, which came off as pretty lame).

Whereas, in many series, it is easy to buy into all of the assumptions and setup; I had a lot of trouble with the set up here.  They looked and acted just like regular people (although they appeared differently to their relatives); and much of the time, they had to find living quarters where their dead had previously lived.  And, many of them had to have real jobs in order live.  In other words, these people who are dead and have the supernatural job of taking the souls of soon-to-be-dead folks, even though much of the show became about them living semi-normal day-to-day lives handing out traffic tickets.

I highly recommend that you watch a couple of shows before buying the DVD or downloading them.  Libraries have DVD's to loan.

If you're at all familiar with Showtime's little-known, cult hit series, "Dead Like Me," you will know that its fans lament its cancellation after a mere two seasons. It is indeed unfortunate that we never had the chance to spend more time in this weird, wonderful, and quirky world. Yet I feel this even more strongly than others do; to me, this series had its soul removed long before it died - to be precise, after Episode 7, shortly following the departure of series creator, Brian Fuller, after episode 5.

For those who are unaware, Fuller left the show due to "creative differences" with the network. Although it's difficult to say exactly what the extent of the conflict was, we know that it revolved in part around Showtime's refusal to keep actress Rebecca Gayheart on board. Gayheart had previously been involved in an automobile incident where she received manslaughter charges. Because of this, Showtime didn't think it was good for their image to have her playing a grim reaper. Her character, Betty Rhomer, was written off and replaced with the somewhat annoying and overbearing Daisy Adair.

Following the simultaneous departure of Fuller and Gayheart, we still are treated to a couple of great episodes. ( I suspect the studio was running on Fuller's leftover ideas). Yet by the time we've reached Episode 8, the quality has certainly dropped a notch. It's easy to ignore this; after all, the writing has the same spark, even if the swearing becomes a little too profuse. Yet the attention to the story and the characters, and a sense of true genius, just isn't there.

"Dead Like Me" was initially the story of a girl called George Lass who is completely indifferent to life, but begins to appreciate life's curiosities after she is killed and becomes a Grim Reaper. However, after the first few episodes, character development suddenly and almost completely grinds to a halt. George's original character arc is dropped and never resurfaces. Her intellectual awakening and determination to go against the system disappears. Despite the occasional offhand complaint, she begins to seem more or less contented with her position as a Reaper. Viewers might interpret this as a natural character progression, and indeed it makes sense that she could have finally sunk into passive acceptance of her role. Yet it is completely unfitting, because the whole initial point of the series was supposed to be George's ironic post-death awakening to the world around her, and how she broke out of her blind acceptance of the status quo.

Meanwhile, the plot veers off into a series of individual side-stories that don't seem to reflect George's character growth. Although initially the episodes were well-focused and clearly displayed a personal journey, eventually it becomes often difficult to see what connection exists, if any, between the different threads of an episode, which don't seem to meet at the end, plot-wise, but sometimes not even thematically.

Meanwhile, we are given scene after scene of George's family, while never seeming to learn very much new about them. In Episode 9, we do get a somewhat closer look at her father Clancy, but it isn't exactly what Fuller intended (which I will explain later), and it doesn't touch on the reasons for his shaky relationship with his wife Joy. George's sister Reggie, and Joy exhibit plenty of room for further exploration. Yet we witness scene after scene of the family's stilted interactions, while never actually learning anything about why they act the way they do.

The willingness to take risks disappears. For the first few episodes, the show is edgier and more irreverent. Until suddenly it becomes almost... normal. The apparently critical remarks about religion disappear, despite that they were so central to the show that the opening scene of the pilot was a cheeky revision of the creation story, based on "Frog and Toad". The instances of blood and gore, something which should be expected in a show about death, vanish as well. The sense of boundless creativity is lost, because the hilarious, clever Rube-Goldberg like situations leading to the deaths suddenly stop. While it was initially impossible to predict how any person would die, suddenly the answer starts to seem perfectly obvious. (A milk man gets run over by a milk truck - how is that for lame?)

There is one instance in which the show does return to its risky nature. However, it comes across as tasteless and sanctimonious political pontificating, rather than a message that has been thoughtfully and properly buried in the script. It is the episode "The Shallow End", with the transgender woman.

We have clues as to how amazing this show could have been. In an interview, Fuller dropped some explanations as to where the story would have gone had he remained in charge. One of the most significant differences would have been the revelation that George's father was gay, meaning that since he was not supposed to procreate, her life was not meant to exist, causing her to value it even more. Instead, the studio decided to play things safe. There are still hints of Clancy's homosexuality, such as in the pilot episode ("Is a friendly hug between two men supposed to last that long?"). Fuller also mentioned that Betty would have returned to take George on a "mission" to "storm the castle". Whatever that means, I'm sure it would have been more interesting than the collection of mostly forgettable side journeys which the show devolves into.

It's another case of a studio sanitizing and damaging a property because they fail to see what viewers really need. This started off as a daring and highly creative series, something like the next "Buffy the Vampire Slayer", except more extraordinary. Then it dwindled down into a bunch of fun but slightly phoned-in episodes. It just should have been better. I can't help but think that the real reason the show is so well-loved is really because of its beginning.

And by the way, if you want a decent finale, watch the movie that concludes the series, Life After Death. It was made without involvement from Showtime and finally addresses a lot of dropped plot threads. While far from perfect, it's a much better send-off than the network gave it.

Don't take any of my complaining to mean that I didn't enjoy Dead Like Me. Even at its worst, it's better than most of television.

Dead Like Me boasts some of the most sympathetic flawed characters in the history of cable television. Terse, acerbic, and heartbreakingly funny narration from George Lass holds together a death mythology that is as logical and unbiased as it is ridiculous.

I'm starting my third watch of this series, and I love it as much as I did when I watched it in real time. The cast is perfect. Ellen Muth could give a master class in eye-rolling, and Cynthia Stevenson, who is always at least excellent, absolutely outdoes herself as Joy. Lass. And that's just the tip of the absurd and ironic iceberg. Jasmine Guy and Mandy Patinkin ("Rube" - perhaps a nod to the manner in which death often occurs) are outstanding.

This is a good companion series to Six Feet Under (they were on different premium cable channels during the same decade), but it is also well worth watching on its own merits.

Dead Like Me is an awesomely entertaining series about a Teenager named Georgia "George" Lass whom meets with an untimely death via an ISS Toilet Seat colliding with her head. Upon death she finds out she has been chosen to be a Reaper. She Struggles between her newly found duties and missing out on her old life. I have watched this entire series from beginning to end several times and still find it just as entertaining as the first time. I would definitely recommend this show to anyone who likes morbid comedy.

Quirky view of life after life for a girl who now lacks as much direction as she did before being killed by a falling space station toilet seat.  Each week souls are "reaped" and people die.  This show is somewhat like passing an accident on the highway.  Once you start an episode you're compelled to watch to see what happens.  Kind of like the table-game clue:  Gravling dropped a piano on secretary on Main street.  Then you get to see the reaction of the newly departed coming to terms with their new reality.

When this show first came out it was marketed all wrong. When it later turned up on Syfy, my daughter & I both enjoyed this series. It has the right combo of acting & writing, hitting upon many fundamental themes of the human experience.

To be fair, I only watched one episode.  The premise is intriguing, what if you were commissioned to spend the afterlife ushering other souls to their future state?  The execution is wearying.  I am guessing that perhaps the primary focal point was to watch this oblivious young woman gain an appreciation for life, but I didn't care.  The characters were flat and lifeless, the storyline, slow to unfold with nothing to beckon me forward.  The laws regarding afterlife behavior were so random, it was clear that they were irrelevant, so there was no tension there either.

I changed it from one star to two, simply because this program, unlike Jessica Jones which I attempted to watch, didn't present the main character's futility in such vulgar and demeaning ways.  Jessica is also living an empty life, punctuated by meaningless sexual encounters and expletives that are bunched together so closely, they carry no weight whatsoever.

But otherwise, they share a common thread.  Life is meaningless, and in this particular case, so is the afterlife.

Dead Like Me is the story of George (Georgia), an 18 year old girl who doesn't know who she is or what she wants, doesn't get along with her mother and ignores her sister.  She dropped out of college and now her mother is pushing her to get up, get a job, and get out of the house.  George is sullen, angry, and not interested in doing much of anything.  But she heads out to a temp agency, gets a job filing, only to end up dead on her first day.  This is where the story really begins, as George is drawn into the world of "Grim Reapers," and finds she has to take people's souls before they die.  She works with Rube (brilliantly portrayed) and a group of strange other Reapers, Betty, Mason, and Roxy.  She struggles to understand her death, her loss of a life before having really lived it, and acts out against her situation...realizing that the consequences of her actions (or lack of) is larger than she could have imagined.

At the same time, her mother, Joy, and her sister, Reggie, struggle on in their loss of George and with each other.  All the while, George keeps going back to the house (she has a different face to the living) because she can't quite let go.  She also finds a new family with her Reapers, as well as the folks at Happy Time temp agency.  George learns more about what it is to be alive after death than she ever did in her life before...and this series takes us along with her.

Best bits are the Reapers hanging out in the Waffle House, the wry witty banter between them, and Rube taking on the role of "father" to this poor, lost girl who finds herself among the ranks of the Undead.  This show really makes you think at times...

As with many series, this starts out with an interesting, tongue-in-cheek, opening.  The writing is brisk and the story is basically, "lucking out" to become a grim reaper, a step ladder effect to reaching whatever else is out there after you die.  So in a sense, you get a glimpse of the future (in knowing your victims, as a grim reaper should) but not too much beyond that.  So you have to rob your victims (if you can) to make ends meet since you're stuck on earth but without a real (paying) job.  And the first episode is cute, but before long devolves into silly and soon, you are hoping for a grim reaper program director to arrive and say, "really??"  But the characters fit, even if the story starts lagging a bit (how many grim reaper tales can you make after pianos fall and people slip on banana peels?).  Overall, a nice change for an hour or so; but beyond that, it might be worth checking something else out, like "Tomorrowland" or "Saving Hope."

I really wasn't sure what to think at first; the main character initially struck me as just another whiny, spoiled child. Her sarcasm and natural cynicism won me over about halfway through the second episode, and I decided to stick with the show a little longer. I'm glad I did; the characters seem a bit wooden at first, but most really develop over time. I have a hard time picking a favorite: Rube, the father figure of the group; Roxy, the tough-as-nails authoritarian figure; Mason, the friendly "big brother" character; or Daisy, the actress with the heart of gold (and maybe a little material desire). They all grow on you after a while, and I'm looking forward to watching the next season!

To be perfectly honest at first it was just my interest in "interesting characters"  and I've always had a soft spot for the characters whom don't seem to really give a crap about anything. And that's the main character Georgia for you , to be honest I think I really felt I related to her , because really to me she just seemed to no more about what she didn't want in life than what she actually did. Which most people do but, typically most people settle with it  while , people like Georgia would rather....die (sorry couldn't help myself) and really I think that's the real story for the gang of reapers in this tale. I like to think that the theme of this humorous tale is that life sucks for everybody but, that doesn't mean you should just give up . And of course it's another little clever gem of Bryan Fuller, whose other works you should defiantly check out, that like most good things in television is cut too soon because of TV's main desire of better ratings and not for better shows.

This is entertaining in an odd way? The series story-line uses death as the vehicle to deliver the story. Some deaths are unexpected, while others seem unfair. All the deaths in the episodes can cause you to contemplate the meaning of it all.

The viewer is introduced to the story through the angst of a young woman (George) who has been thrown into the role of a grim reaper after her death. Grim Reapers, are a group of dead people who liberate the soul from the body of the soon to die. Georgia the title character "reaper" is taught the ropes of her new role by fellow Reapers. All played magnificently by other actors.

Only 2 seasons!  Still worth it. When this show was first aired, I gave up after the pilot. The protagonist is not like-able. She's just an angstey underachieving teenage college drop out who gets hit on the head and is now a dead, angstey underachieving college dropout. Even the allure of Mandy Patinkin and a hot Brit guy couldn't keep my interest. If I'd felt motivated to stick with it, I would have watched her character develop and blossom. The rest of the ensemble, and this is an ensemble show, also warms to their characters, and by the end of the first season, I couldn't wait to watch the second, and sadly, last season. They manage to tie up a few ends, and I hear there's a movie of it, but DEAD LIKE ME should have had a long run on TV. Give it a chance and binge watch Season One. I'm betting you'll be back for the second year.

I'm a big fan of any story about dead people reflecting on their lives.  Though Georgia isn't maybe the most likable person, I can identify with her.  She was someone in life who didn't do much because she felt it was pointless, but then she dies and regrets all the lost opportunities.  We watch her family struggle with her death.  Through flashbacks, we see how she became the person she was.

Then there are George's lovable co-workers--both her fellow reapers and her day job.  I was upset to see the curly hair red-head leave.  I didn't really like her replacement at first, but Daisy grew on me.  It ended kind of on a heavy note that goes into Season 2, but I did like it.  I think the show deals more with George's anger at dying so young at the end, so it gets a little more intense then.

One of my favorites shows that died too soon (pun intended).  George, the sarcastic protagonist, dies young in a freak accident and becomes a reaper. The storyline follows the trials and tribulations of the new reaper with her new reaper "family," and her living family as they cope with her loss. The writing is witty and original and the storyline seamlessly transposes between the sadness of loss and the humor that some people use to deal with their grief.

The series is hard to get into.  The character development is such that initially you like none of the principal people.  But, as I got into it, it reminded me of the character development in Northern Exposure.  The principal protagonist grows as she learns life lessons (albeit after death).  Mandy Patinkin is great as sort of a Greek chorus (much like Chris in the Morning in Northern Exposure).  I must admit, if I hadn't had time on my hands, I might not have made the effort to watch past the first two episodes.  It was a major surprise to begin to hear the kind of philosophical musings from Mandy that I had so enjoyed in Northern Exposure.  After that revelation, I began to give the series more of a chance and I'm glad that I did.  Each of the characters develop into people about whom you actually care.  The are some real laugh out loud moments as well.  Give it a chance.

When Dead Like Me came out, I liked it so much that I set aside time to watch it every week.

The first episode was great.  The concept was promising. The casting seemed perfect. It's still hard to imagine anyone else playing the lead character, the slacker reaper, George.

As the weeks passed, problems became apparent.  There were interesting elements in every episode, but other elements that  dragged the show down.  It's odd that the writers couldn't see the problems, because viewers could, and bailed on the show in large numbers as a result.

What worked about the series were the relationships among the "undeads," particularly George and Rube. The actor playing Rube brought an intensity that was the perfect counterbalance to George's apathy.  The revelations in the final episodes about his character and his family, particularly his daughter, were nicely crafted and beautifully acted.

What ruined Dead Like Me were the seemingly endless interludes dwelling on George's family.  In a typical episode, we might see George's mother argue with her sister about what to wear or what to have for dinner; watch George's mother be caustic and nasty to her father; watch George's father look morose and wander off; watch George's mother sell her house; watch George's sister steal toilet seats and deny that she was stealing them; watch George's sister make lunch; watch George's sister try on makeup for the first time; watch George's sister stop using makeup; watch George's mother have an affair; watch George's father have an affair; watch George's mother and sister move into a new house; watch the family's dog get sick; watch the family's dog get hit by a car; etc., etc., etc. Most of this had little if anything to do with the episode's main story arc. It became a tedious kind of filler, truly difficult after a while to keep watching.

It's one thing for the characters to be trapped in an endless kind of purgatory; it's another thing to ask the audience to endure it, week after week, when it's clear that it's pointless and going nowhere.  Audiences bailed, and I'd say this was the reason.  So Dead Like Me died young, like its protagonist. So it goes.

I am a Bryan Fuller fan who has enjoyed Wonderfalls, Pushing Daisys and it all started with Dead Like Me.  IMHO, this was his best.  The fact it was cable meant it wasn't restricted and had an amazing cast.  Ellen Muth provided a strong character as Georgia the newest Undead.  George was funny, indifferent, strong and vulnerable as the lead.  Jasmine Guy, Callum Blue, Manny Patinkin and Cythina Stevenson were amazing as the cast. The story revolves around George death and adjusting to her life as a working member of the Undead.

Imaginative story of the reaper social class, never pretty, but in this case a good mix of personalities that play well off of each other.  It's truly a classic in the sense that even when you hoped you had forgotten the series--you think about it anyway and you want to see it again. This makes it a "cult favorite" forever--and in this sense, it has that look and feel all the way.

On the subject of reality, at times it seems either a little too real or a little too fantastic. You're forced to go back and forth between the two; it's difficult to come up with a final decision.  It's also a bit on the depressing side, which can weigh heavy on your soul, but that's eye-opening all on its own, isn't it?
Great show

Funny, engaging characters and voice over, and a few poignant moments. I enjoyed it very much. The premise is that some people who die are selected as "reapers" who collect the souls of those about to pass away. The reapers are "undead" who have to work to earn money for food, clothing and shelter. They take with them into death the emotional issues of their lives which they may be able to resolve in their afterlife in some way. Of course, complications ensue. The undead are forbidden from contacting former family and friends. If they do, there are consequences.

I enjoy the quirky main character, and I'm looking forward to starting season 2.
Thoughtful, provocative, and often moves quickly between laughter and tears.

The ideas presented in this series offers some comfort to the grieving simply by offering a light hearted approach to death (transition). As a grief counselor I can see the benefits to such stories and recommend them to those having a hard time accepting the untimely transition of a loved one. Kudos to the writers and the incredibly talented cast of characters. It is both funny, thought provoking and compassionate at the same time.
Great series!
Love the dry, sardonic humor.

I love this wacky show! Millie got whacked by a toilet seat in an explosion and passed. But came back as a reaper.  She and other reapers are in charge of passing on others who have been chosen. Each of the reapers has a story to tell. The actress playing Millie has a unique personality, perfect for the part of a pessimistic reaper. Her home life when she was alive had a lot to do with it. I like how she is trying to keep in contact with them. I love her Miss Perky boss who is totally opposite of her. If you like shows that are a little different, you will love it!
I never saw it when it aired on HBO. And I saw an edited version on ScyFi. Nice to see it unedited.

Love this show!  Totally off the wall and quirky but really well-written and character development is very good, in my opinion.  Just enough humor and drama.  And free streaming with Amazon Prime is terrific!

Thankfully I didn't pay since it's free with Prime instant streaming video. Normally I don't review shows but I'm writing in hopes of stopping Amazon from making suggestion for me based on the fact that I watched 2 and a half episodes of this wretched series.  I'd forgotten that it ever existed until I saw it available on Prime. Vaguely remembered watching a few episodes when it first aired and thought it might be fun to watch again. More like slow mental torture. No wonder Showtime cancelled it after two seasons; it deserved a visit from the grim reaper after season 1.  Badly written, badly acted, full of plot holes, and tedious beyond human endurance (mine, anyway).  Side note:  I got a big laugh from an old review written years ago proclaiming that Dead Like Me would live on in history as one of TV's greatest shows long after The Sopranos was forgotten!

Such a funny and cool little show about the after life.
A lot of times it makes no sense but if you can get past the often illogical situations and remember it's just a comedy then it is a lot of fun. If it had lasted one more season it would probably have been great.

A young girl meets a sudden violent death.  Rather than drift on up to heave, she finds that she has been chosen to be a reaper, destined to free the souls of soon to be victims of violent death.

Alive, she had been goalless, passionless and ambivilent about life.  Now undead she begins to come alive and appreciate what life has to offer.  Surrounded by quirkey characters she sets about completing each days soul reaping mission.

The premise is odd, the writing is good and the cast is terrific.  Well worth a watch.

Dead Like Me is one of those one of a kind series that manages to grab you and not let go.  From the pilot episode featuring a very young Jodelle Ferland, the series kept getting better and better.  I continue to watch, even now, and find little things I missed on the first time through.  I would recommend this series to anyone as an awesome study on life.
GOOD SHOW TO WATCH

As a teen I really enjoyed this show, and for me even then, that would have been a surprise to most. Because I'm all about shows with horror, action, sci-fi and sex, drugs and rock and roll.

But as an adult, I found myself skipping multiple episodes because the same things literally happened time and time again. The show didn't really have dynamic conflicts and the characters, well they remained the same. Which is fine for a comedy but for dramas people want to see growth or they want to be able to connect with the characters.

The main conflict and the only real continuous one, will George ever reveal herself to her family, is the only conflict that drags out for two season.

The one interesting part of season two only lasted two episodes and ended in a lack luster and anti climatic way. Since I did enjoy it as a teen and some episodes were funny and interesting even to this day, I'll give it three stars.

It sucks now with my seasoned eyes, I can see why it was canceled after two seasons.

The show was canceled  before the story was completed so there is a made for TV movie to wrap things up.

Not quite dead folks that have to work for a living (pun intended) and collect the souls of the about-to-die as a part-time job doesn't grab and hold my attention like a good mystery. Maybe my imagination doesn't stretch as well as it used to so I'll not say anything bad about this show. The acting is okay but the whole idea just doesn't get it for me. My suggestion? Don't hold everything I say against the show. Watch a couple of episodes and see what happens. You may like it.

I always enjoyed this series and am very glad to find it on Amazon to stream. George, a/k/a Peanut to Rube, is a newly dead 'Reaper' tasked with collecting souls from the living on the cusp of death. Rube (Mandy Pantinkin), doles out the soul collection assignments on 3-M Post-Its usually from the table of his favorite eatery, Der Waffle Haus. If you've watched and enjoyed the movie Odd Thomas [HD], this series is for you. If you enjoy this series and never seen Odd Thomas, those books by Dean Koontz/that movie is also for you.

A show about a group of grim reapers who take souls may seem, well, icky. With "Dead Like Me" you care about the characters, who go about normal everyday business except for when they get their "reap" assignmnets (on post-it notes). (In the show itself, the reapers don't wear robes or hoods, but ordinary clothes.)

This was such an original show.  The opening scene of George and the flaming toilet just set the tone.  All the characters had such unique personalities with their own quirks and motivations.  Noone was ever entirely a "good" person.  And the premise of being reapers and George interacting with her family even after death.  Awesome stuff!

"Dead Like Me" Season 1 is a breath of fresh air when it comes to television.  This quirky show has an outstanding cast of actors who make the premise of being a "reaper" believable.  Oh, what is a "reaper?"  A reaper is one who has died but for some unknown reason, is still of this earth,( although he has  a different physical appearance from his previous life) and whose job is to assist the soul of the soon to be dead.  Ellen Muth is wonderful as "George", an uninspired slacker who gets killed by a hurling toilet seat from a space station reentering the atmosphere.  Her boss is Rube, the talented Mandy Patinkin, uses post-it notes to hand out the assignments to the small group of reapers who meet daily at a German themed Waffle House.  It sounds strange but this odd little gem of a show  had me hooked and looking forward to the next episode.  The stories can be funny and poignant, yet each one made me ponder the importance of living life to the fullest and showing appreciation to the people in your life.  The only tragedy of this show is that it only lasted for 2 seasons.
Not a cookie cutter show. Gallows humor--sad, funny, affecting. Interesting characters, great stories, very good acting. Too bad there's only two seasons to watch.

Love this series!!  It totally rocks.  Love the drama.  Love the humor.  Just finished season 1 and can't wait to start season 2 and see what is in store for Georgia.  Thinking of buying both seasons on DVD.

You could create an entirely new series out of all the logical inconsistencies in this one, but an entertaining and well-written show all the same. Ellen Muth plays George, a pitch-perfect disengaged girl who learns more about living after her death than she ever cared to while alive. Surrounding her are several other misfit refugees from the once-living, all lead by Rube, the immediate supervisor in their grim-reaping responsibilities, played by a relentlessly no-nonsense Mandy Patinkin. Parallel to their story lines, the series follows the splintering (and growth) of George's family along existing fault lines in the aftermath of her death.

Sharp writing and excellent acting make this an enjoyable and worthwhile series if you enjoy the premise. Just don't squint too closely at some of the ongoing plot details about the co-existence of the dead and undead.

Dead Like Me is just one of many examples of shows that were fantastic, but never received a big enough following while they were running to stay alive during the television run. Yet, after the show had been off the air, it began to spread by word of mouth and friends passing along DVDs and videos of the show, giving it the cult following it has today. Poor Bryan Fuller...between this, Pushing Daisies, and Wonderfalls, he has had one show after another cancelled long before its time. (sorry Heroes fans, the show got a little long in the tooth and lost its way to deserve more seasons)

The pacing and humor of the show are spot-on, and each character is well-developed and evolves as the show continues. George goes from having no direction in life to finding little things here and there to live for as she begins to find her way in the group. Rube, who is mysterious and guarded at first, begins to reveal pieces of himself that both satisfy and leave one wondering more about his past. Mason may seem a drug and love-obsessed fool at first, but shows that he notices more than it would seem, and actually has quite the sweet side. Roxy probably changes the least in the show, but builds relationships with the other characters that make her invaluable to the fabric of the show. Finally, Daisy makes huge strides through the show, going from a flippant harlot into a woman showing flashes of deeper loneliness and emotion. The rest of the Lass family rounds out the cast, but the stars are clearly the reaper gang.

Each reaping features a little bit of a lesson, revealing just a bit more about characters, the job of a reaper, the "rules" and more. It lends forward momentum to a show and keeps it from being formulaic. Indeed, Dead Like Me is anything but procedural. Some might be offended by the constant swearing throughout the show, but I think it grounds the language from becoming too philosophical and clever at times.

All in all, this is one of my favorite shows, and I still watch it every few years and remember just how brilliant it was.

Dead Like Me was a quirky series about death & the afterlife.  Becoming a Grim Reaper after her death, she struggles with the concept of relieving souls shortly before death so they go to Heaven rather than be trapped in their dead body.  She has to get a job to support herself because she doesn't get paid for Reaping!
  The series predates a lot of the horror TV series involving vampires and the like.  I like the show because of the unique concept and acting.

Showing the daily lives of reapers, their preference of meeting in a local waffle house, and using sticky notes guiding them to their next targets creates a humorous show.  All characters are fun to watch and the story line focus varies from episode to episode but follows a timeline as well.  Good series.
Interesting idea for a show different and enjoyable.  I would recommend watching.  Only half way through first season but expect to watch the remainder.
Quirky and fun but we didn't know about it when it was on. It only has two seasons but they are different.

The writers of this series are obviously top notch.  The dialog was always clever, the plots are smart, the concept is brilliant the direction is superb and the "soapiness" level is just right. Because the script/directing is so good the acting is also superb; Ellen Muth and Mandy Patinkin make the show as does Cynthia Stevens and Britt McKillip.  Why on earth it got canned I'll never know, maybe some influential bible thumping republican shareholders at MGM got upset with the less than Christian take on "life after death".  Certainly if you're a religious nut this series is likely not going to work for you.  If you have an open, intelligent mind and want to escape into an interesting tongue-in-cheek world of new ideas and brilliant well written satire then this is well worth watching.

The premise is appealing:  someone, somewhere, knows when and where each of us will leave this life, and there will be another someone on hand to remove the soul from its body and escort it to "the lights."  Removing the soul prior to death allows the victim to escape pain and fear upon death.  It's a comforting concept.
So who removes these souls?  People who themselves have suffered mortal injuries, but who--for whatever reason--remain "alive" to reap the souls of those who will die.  We never know why these "undead" reapers weren't immediately ushered to their own "lights."
The show focuses on a small family of reapers, five in all, with a team leader (Mandy Patimkin) responsible for issuing each day's assignments--name, time, and place only.  It's up to the individual reaper to be there, on time.  So we see lots of folk leaving their lives in some interesting ways.  Their bodies are dead, but their spirit selves materialize immediately, so it's not at all gory.  Even the death scenes aren't gory--they remind one of the scene in "Wizard of Oz," when we know that the wicked witch has met her fate by seeing her feet poking out from beneath the house.
The reapers, in between their daily reaping assignments, are expected to be self-supporting.  They work at jobs just like the rest of us.  They no longer look like their former selves, but they have retained all their lifetime memories.  The key character, an 18-year-old malcontented girl, has remained in her hometown and, despite her boss' repeated warnings, continues to check up on her real-life family (who, of course, cannot recognize her).  So we get to see how the death of one daughter is affecting the surviving family.
If you're wondering how this could be humorous, you'll simply have to look at an episode.  Black comedy, perhaps, but it's also often quite touching.
Oh, one of my favorite aspects: even animals have souls, and reapers have not forgotten them.

The idea was fresh (at the time it was originally aired 2003) and done well.  The cast were believable in their roles and everyone fit their parts perfectly, especially "George" played by Ellen Muth, she is a joy to watch.  The writing was excellent!  It is fast paced, witty, thought provoking, and keeps the story going each episode from beginning to end always leaving you ready to click the next episode.  This might not be for some due the subject matter of the "undead", but for me, I was sorry there were only two seasons made!  (I saw the movie, but I wouldn't recommend it).  I've watched the seasons a couple of times now and I've started the series again with a friend.  Give it a try if you are looking for something different, thought provoking, well done, excellent writing and acting, along with getting some good laughs.

My wife and I bought the first season based on the amazing number of five-star reviews here.  We definitely regret doing so.  We haven't found much of anything to enjoy so far in this first season--the scripts are derivative and repetitive, the dialogue is trivial and uninspired, and many of the situations are just simply silly--they require far too much suspension of disbelief in order to buy what's going on.  We both love the premise and hoped for more, but we didn't get it.  The feeling I get is that the makers are trying too hard with everything, including casting.  Nothing seems natural, and everything seems forced, with a "this will work here" feeling behind it all.

And while the main character seems to be created to be confused and overwhelmed, she comes across mostly as whiny--and her voice for the narrative voiceovers is simply ineffective.  And while I don't have any problem with vulgarity if it fits in the context of the show, here the curse words seem nothing more than gratuitous.  And much of what goes on seems contrived in order to create confusion that allows for plot twists, such as giving only the initials of the people who are going to die.  It's a contrivance that makes no sense at all, and that is also fairly insulting to a viewer's intelligence.  And the dead having bodies and having to eat and have jobs?  This is another contrivance that allows them to put the main character in a dead-end office job that is one of the most lifeless and boring settings that I've ever seen.

It's interesting for a couple of episodes, but our interest died out quickly, and we don't feel any desire at all to see the rest of the season.  We don't care about any of the characters, and we don't care about what will happen to them--it'll more than likely be more of the same.

First episode was lengthy and long winded, hard to watch all the way through. But all shows following we're wonderful and enriching with great little life stories. I highly recommend this series and truly wish there we're more.

A creative use of post-it notes, and a recently dead girl having to adjust to her new "job" as one of many Grim Reapers - great premise. She takes the place of the Reaper who took her soul, and joins four others in the daily job of finding their 'person' and helping them cross over, while learning about herself and the world around her.
I really enjoyed this while it was running, and saddened when it left the air.
It is a great series with excellent acting and an unusual premise.  Make sure you get season 2 as well.

I periodically revisit this series for a reminder of the preciousness of life and the fragility and mutability of human relationships.  The writing was witty and provocative (at least for the first season) and the acting was strong, particularly Ellen Muth as George and Cynthia Stevenson as her frustrated mother Joy.  Little touches (such as the perennial yodeling background music in Der Waffle Haus and the frequent use of the jenga tower as a metaphor for how intertwined we all are with each other) provided a rhythm and flow to "Dead Like Me."  It's fun to watch and at the same time it is sometimes painful to see George's family struggling in the wake of her death.  The bizarre ways in which people die are kind of amazing also.

Watch it.

Bryan Fuller has an odd, often macabre sense of humor.  He also has a unique and interesting cadence to his dialog that is apparent here, although truly showcased in his later series, "Pushing Daisies".

In this wonderful series, the protagonist is a disaffected young woman who dies and becomes a grim reaper. But, she doesn't just die, she's killed by a toilet seat falling from a space station. Some of the souls taken by this new reaper die is spectacularly silly ways, and the reapers need to take the souls before the grim deed occurs. Of course, all of this, from the bizarre deaths to her nickname among reapers (Toilet-seat Girl), to having to earn a living and pay her own way even after she dies, adds to her sense that the world isn't fair. While she starts out focused on life's unfairness to her, she begins to become refocused on how life isn't fair to anyone. Her growth, as she learns true empathy for others and finally discovers the value of family, the macabre sense of humor, and Fuller's fascinating dialog provide a richly rewarding television experience.

If you like dry, morbid humor, you will love DLM. This episode was particularly poignant. This is the first time we see the parents' marriage trajectory, and realize they were once a happy nuclear family living a very traditional life with apparent satisfaction. We see how that over time produces not only bitterness in their relationship, but depression and a generally negative outlook in their daughters.

We also get a deeper insight into Daisy, beyond her self-presentation to the world. And we see a new side of some of the other characters as well. "Maybe we are all just temps," is the episode's key line. And in that realization of the ephemeral nature of our existence, within a context of recording the last thoughts of the dying "for posterity," we find the essence of human life. We are here but a short while, and when we die it is hardly original, nor in the DLM universe is it generally very happy in the end. Every joy is fleeting. And even death is just another assignment. Yet we can be there for each other, surround ourselves with people we love, and that is the redeeming possibility.

Somehow they manage to make all that moroseness humorous and heartfelt. Great writing and great acting. This is my second time watching this series, and though it is more of a belly laugh the first time through, it never fails to entertain.

Dead Like Me originally aired on Showtime from 2003-2004 however it was not until 2007 I first discovered this gem of a show. I still wonder how it took so long for me to ever hear about it. Coincidentally, it's much like Quantum Leap in that it is one of my favorite series ever (#1 actually) and it was all because of the Sci-Fi Channel and their marathons I became a fan.

Dead Like Me is a show that follows five main characters (one leaves after the fifth episode to be replaced by another) who just happen to be death--literally. The show's main focus is an 18 year old woman named George (short for Georgia) Lass who is killed in the first episode.

The way it works in-universe is that there are multiple grim reapers--though we never see THE Grim Reaper--around the world, many (or all...it's never explicitly said as we meet a few non-main character individual reapers) work in groups. These groups all work under a specific category. For example, one reaper in the second season takes the souls of people who die of natural causes. George and the other main characters work with the "External Influence Division" (murder, suicide, accident). In order to become a reaper, it's more or less the luck of the draw. To become one, the reap has to be the reaper's last one. In George's case, she was. Last reap's must take their reaper's place when said reaper moves on, or gets promoted as the show puts it.

One might wonder how someone like George can go about doing their thing if they are dead. Perhaps wondering, wouldn't someone, especially family, notice? Well, reapers often two appearances--their true appearance, and what the living world sees.

Dead Like Me is a character-driven plot. Very much so, dare I say. But that's no problem as the characters play off one another so well.

The main characters include George, an 18 year old college dropout with a twinge of misanthropy and social alienation (it's noted on the commentary that no one her own age is present at her funeral), Mason, a constant screw-up alcoholic drug user who died in the 1966 and this reviewer's favorite character, Roxy, a tough-as-nails meter-maid and later police officer, Betty who is replaced after five episodes by the seemingly self-absorbed and shallow actress Daisy Adair who died in the 1920s, and the leader of the pack, Rube, a complex father-figure to the group, and especially George. Wildly different people in terms of personality, but they all play off each other and interact to the point of it being almost amazing.

In the wake of George's death is her parents and younger sister who struggle to deal with it in their own ways. This is just to name a few though. There are other recurring characters as well you easily will love seeing on screen.

One of my favorite things about season one is watching George grow gradually going from an 18 year old who doesn't want the responsibility of being a reaper, trying her best to shirk her duty, and taking people's souls to accepting it and having no problems with doing what must be done.

And I believe overall that's what season one is about--George's journey and growth. The black humor, and surprisingly poignant moments peppered throughout, work well together also. It's not a show where one ruins the other, thankfully.

Though it's not a show everyone will like (just like everything else, we all have different opinions and tastes), would I recommend checking it out? That is a whole-hearted yes.

If you must see for yourself, stream it from Netflix, try before you buy.  Maybe you'll like it more than I did.

I like many others began watching this series long after it was cancelled.  The show was not cancelled due to a lack of ratings, in fact it was doing very well for Showtime.  Budget problems with MGM and subsequent related issues spelled it's demise.  Few productions capture the audience in the way that Dead Like Me have, inspiring a league of devoted followers and fans, perhaps even cementing Ellen Muth as an icon of the intelligent sarcastic witty attractive grim reaper she played so well.  I highly recommend watching both seasons to completion, if possible in the order they were produced.  The dynamics and interaction between cast members was a treat, albeit one clearly targeting the adult audience due to the adult language and sometimes realistically harsh interactions between the group of reapers that is the subject of the series.  This series is not about death, it is about the facilitators who help people transition from life to death and how they deal with themselves while trying to exist and work in the real world amongst the living.

Dead Like Me had me laughing, crying and even seriously contemplating the direction and goals of my own life at times.  However the witty humor and tainted outlook on life, along with the perfectly fitting voice of narration by Ellen Muth kept things light enough to classify DLM as a comedy drama that never disappointed me by resorting to slapstick simpleton humor just to get a laugh.

Highly recommended.

I am a very late discoverer of this show.  But upon discovering it a few days ago, I watched both seasons nonstop.  Describing this show as a "feel good" experience seems like a very odd label, but in reality, nails what it is.  This isn't your sentimental "Touched By an Angel" approach (which wasn't a bad show don't get me wrong :P) or your doom-and-gloom "The End is Neigh!" mentality.  It is a show which illustrates how non-morbid the truth about death is.  Watching this show brought the line that Maximus uttered in Gladiator to mind: "Death smiles at us all. All a man can do is smile back."  This is exactly what happens to George.  She finally learns neither to woe her demise or be apathetic to it.  You just have to smile back.
I have seen some of the shows on TV. Now I am able to see the entire first season.

I'm an atheist so the thought of an afterlife doesn't mean anything to me, but despite that I really enjoyed the series.
The series is about a group of grim reapers, who take souls, and how they interact and associate with the living. What makes the show interesting is George, the main character, (played by Ellen Muth ) narrates the shows as if you were in her mind. She has a unique perspective. The cast is excellent.
  This episode is good but if you're going to watch this series , you should start at the beginning.

If you haven't seen "Dead Like Me" and have a high tolerance for bad language, you owe it to yourself to check it out.  Apart from the fact that this was a Showtime series (and thus the "TV Ratings" gloves were off for the producers), this show is a one-two punch of being very entertaining...and sucking you in the more episodes you watch.  Halfway through series one the writing goes from "good" to "excellent" and the characters start to come into their own.

If you're not familiar with the concept, this is as spoiler-free as I can make it:  when some people die, they don't get to "move on" to the hereafter.  Instead, they are called "Reapers", and they've been put in charge of being present when people die.  Living half in and half out of the real world, Reapers have to both tag the unfortunate for death (to release their souls) and guide the newly-departed souls into the beyond.  The show doesn't try to put any religious messages into the concept--instead, there's something amusing about the way they make reaping seem like yet another bureaucratic process that keeps the wheels of civilization turning.  The point isn't the reaping--the point is the characters, and that's why it's really interesting.

It's a real pity this show only lasted two seasons (and a separate movie)--I have a feeling it could have gone a lot farther.  The comedy is grim and macabre, but not mean-spirited.  It's also not very gory.  The only drawback is that the placement of bad language can be jarring at times.

Not like me - dead, that is! This is a really cute series - one of those shows you just never forget it's so different.

The series, Dead Like Me, is kind of a dark comedy. The series is about a young woman, 18 year old Georgia, who's met with an untimely death when a toilet seat comes crashing to earth from the space station MIR. It's a funny scene - not just because she's hit by a toilet seat which has burst into flames because it's falling from space, but because in an ironic twist Georgia (George) is at lunch on her first day of work, looks up, and sees the toilet seat heading straight for her! At first she doesn't seem to understand she's dead and is in great denial. George finds herself stuck between life and death, appointed to be a reaper - a job she wants no part of.

As a reaper George is still "in the flesh", but no longer appears as George to anyone who knew her before. She "lives" a somewhat normal "life" in that she has a job working in an office, but also meets with the other reapers every day and is given her assignment - who she has to reap that day and at what time. When the reapers touch the intended person, they die, and go on to ... where ever it is they go when they die! On occasion one of the reapers is late, or misses their appointment - which has various unfortunate consequences.

George never seems to get over the fact that she's died, and keeps going back to check up on/spy on/reminisce about her family - something reapers are forbidden to do. There are some pretty funny results of her doing this, especially with her mother - who percieves her as some kind of stalker after she runs into George more than once lurking around their house. There are also some pretty sad moments when it comes to her younger sister, Reggie - who also can't seem to get over Geogia's death. After George's death Reggie rebels by stealing toilet seats from neighbors and school, and hanging them from a tree in a "secret place". It's funny in a ironic way.

George's mother, played by Cynthia Stevenson, is an uptight, cold character even before George's death, but afterward takes out her grief on her husband and Reggie. Reggie grows up to be a pretty girl, but she's always kind of alienated from her peers.

Minor characters: In her new "life", other than being a reaper, George is employed in an office where her boss, Deloris Herbig, is an odd, motherly character. At home Deloris has her own reality show of sorts - which George finds out about when she has to move in with Deloris and finds herself broadcast on the internet! Deloris has an elderly cat, Murray - who's love of Deloris' life.

Main Characters: The "head reaper" is played by Manny Pantankin (Rube) - who is ideal in the part. I don't think there's anyone else who could play the part so well - as we later find out in the movie - which was a huge disappointment to my husband and myself. The other reapers are played by Jasmine Guy (Roxy) who is wonderful as a hard-nosed meter maid. Laura Harris (Daisy Adair) who is beautiful and stuck up. She was an actress in her day who just can't give up on the fact that she'll never act again. To Daisy all the afterlife is a stage. Callum Blue (Mason) a British con man, who's always looking for a con, and is too good looking even for himself - in his opinion! And Rebecca Gayheart (Betty) a former dancer who's character is happy and optimistic.

I originally got the 1st season of "Dead Like Me" as a present for our oldest daughter, but she never watched them, so my husband and I "borrowed" them. Once we started watching we had to see them all! After watching the first 2 seasons my husband and I searched and were thrilled to find the 3rd season, but then were so disappointed when we found the series ended after 3 seasons.

A movie of "Dead Like Me" came out after the series ended. I'm not sure if they were trying to revive the series with a few new characters or what, but there were no other shows after the movie. Manny Pantankin and Laura Harris were not in the movie - which was a huge loss. If the series had gone on it just wouldn't have been the same w/o those key characters. We didn't enjoy the movie because it seemed darker, not funny, and just didn't measure up to the series.
I saw the first five episodes on the internt so I knew I liked the series.

I have to admit that the first time I heard about this tv show I was a little worried. It was as show about an eighteen year old girl, that gets killed by a toilet seat? WHAT? I gave the show a chance, and I was very pleasantly surprised.  I ended up LOVING the show.  It's filled with dark humor and gets you wondering about various things in your life (or at least it did for me...).
The main story line is about George, an eighteen yr old who dropped out of college, and gets killed by a toilet seat from a de-orbiting space station.  After dying she meets Rube, to fills her in that she is going to become a grim reaper, taking souls from people who are about to die violent deaths.  The show follows George as she tried to deal with her death, the trouble that is happening with her sister, and parents, and her new job.  Needless to say she has her hands full.
The show is well cast with Ellen Muth playing George, the main character that gets killed by the toilet seat, Mandy Patinkin playing Rube, the boss of the reapers, Callum Blue playing Mason, the British drug user and alcoholic, Jasmine Guy playing Roxy, the temperamental meter maid who likes keeping people in line, and Laura Harris who plays Daisy, a bubbly "actress", that seems to have slept with all the classic film stars.
Overall I have to say that I have just started the whole "Dead Like Me" series a few days ago, and I couldn't stop watching it.  I'm already on season two!  If you like dark comedy then you will love this show!

The only disappointing thing about the "Dead Like Me" is that it had to come to an end. I love the irreverent and slightly dark humor. It is wonderful to watch a show that is truly funny without being dirty or stupid.

Death can be funny and inteligent and... can put you to think about your own life. And that's great. So, you have here a wonderful show, not funny all the time but extremely well done, with an extraordinary plot.
Shame it was only 2 seasons, but, on second thought, that is good because they haven't had the time to ruin it.
If you want well written televisison, this is for you.
