There is no nudity in this first season but the language can be rather harsh for some.  Check it out.

Having been a little disappointed to see Mandy Patankin doing cholesterol medicine commercials on TV, I was delighted to find some of his recent REAL acting jobs.  I had never heard of this show, but luckily found it in a recent DVD Blow-Out sale on Amazon.  Mandy is a great actor and after reading some posted reviews, knew I had to see this gem of a series.  This show was perfectly cast and written in a way to open our eyes to the opportunities we let get by us.  Time's a wastin!  Spread some joy every day!  Leave a large hole where you used to be!  Let everyone feel blessed their path crossed yours!  SHARE-TEACH-LOVE...and for those of us who believe in re-incarnation, pass the purest soul you can.  Enjoy this series and pass it along.

I had barely gotten started watching DlM, when I found out it was not picked up for a 3rd season. I was SOOO disappointed, but, fortunately for me(better late than never I guess), I have seen nearly, if not all of the episodes and always keep a search for it when it is re-running.

Anyhow, short of just probably a handful of television programs, Dead like Me is one of the best I have ever seen. It mixes just about every human(and "non-human" or dead/undead)emotion there is simultaneously and is so convincing that these situations almost seem possible, whether or not you "believe" in an afterlife or not. I guess due in part to the fact that our "reapers" are just your average, everyday people who did have lives, families, careers, problems, etc. and that nobody is "safe" from some bizarre, freak accident when you are out there in the world, whether it be on an airplane, or just walking down the street on your lunchbreak.

I think the casting of this show was impeccable especially with Ellen Muth as "George/Millie" and Mandy Patinkin as "Rube, the supe". Her glum and sort of "whatever/GTH" attitude toward things just really blends well with her counterparts and I especially like the relationship between she and Rube. He seems sort of like the "father-figure", but no-nonsense boss that someone with her attitude needs to push and motivate her along. Then, Callum Blue.....I just ADORE him. He can be such an irresponsible screw-up, but at the same time does show signs of tenderness and caring toward others as well. It's almost like instead of being a 20 or 30something bloke from the 60's drug era, he could be the little boy down the street always into something and coming up with the "next great idea or scam". Then of course the rest of the cast is great as well, and I especially like the little gal who plays George's lil sis.

To summarize, a VERY entertaining and thought provoking show, in my opinion. I just wish it had received the notoriety and following that shows like "Six Feet Under"(another great one), "Sex and the City" and some of the other cable shows received. I am sure, if it had, we would still be watching new episodes to this day!

I absolutely loved the first season of Dead Like Me.  They casted the characters so well.  I'm a big Mandy Patinkin fan myself and he was wonderful.  The characters were so well built you could really relate to each one and their stories.  I best related to George.  Her attitude and expressions were perfect for the character she portrayed.
Dead Like Me is darkly funny and surpisingly moving. Great characters. Adictive. You will watch the whole season in one day.
I loved this show so I had to buy the seasons. Sucks that they took it off air but I heard its coming back. This set is highly recommended.

This is one of the best TV shows to come out in years.  The series is a black comedy, to be sure, but it deals with
serious issues such as what respect the dead deserve, the need to
value each day as precious, the forging of family relationships,
the nature of Good and Evil.  Nevertheless, this is a very funny show, offbeat, but vastly entertaining.  My favorite scene: one of the female grim reapers has a day job as a meter maid. One outraged citizen demands that she take the ticket back and assaults the meter maid.  In anger, she lifts out the citizen's soul, strangles it, and then puts it back into his body.  When she meets him again, he has turned into a pacifist who has made a shrine to the meter maid.  Later when she has his truck towed, he responds that he understands her..."you are a vengeful God."  Another wonderful scene is the depiction of
the trauma that a younger sister has when her older sister
(the starlet of the show) dies from a toilet seat plunging from space from a Russian space station. The young girl steals toilet seats from her school and neighbors, hangs the seats as leaves
on her private tree where the sister goes to be alone.  Indeed some of the episodes are quite touching.  For those looking for a program that transcends the formulaic plots of other shows, this is the one to see.
This is a great series. Very enjoyable. A little different, but great.

WHY do the good die young? Shows like this are cancelled despite the fact that they win awards and are very well written and acted. What a shame. This was one of the best series I have ever seen. Character development was coming along nicely and so were plot twists. The only thing to look forward to when you finish this series is that there is one more season, season two.

During a recent bout of the flu, I lay on my couch and watched the whole first season of this great show. It's quirky, funny, clever, and yet truthful. The acting is excellent. My only real gripe is with the overuse of flashbacks to previous episodes of the show; this suggests to me that the show's budget was too low, as using flashbacks obviously saves money on filming new live action. This aside, it's a fun show which will probably appeal to lovers of 'Six Feet Under' and 'Buffy'.
I did not catch this series when it originally aired. If you like twisted humor this is the show for you. I love it!!!!!!

We need more shows like this.  Thought-provoking, poignant, with lots of witty sarcasm on the side. This is for people who are tired of formulaic, mainstream "entertainment" and prefer their TV "outside the box."
All the charactors are in sync, both my wife and I laugh our heads off. Great Show

Love the show, I got hooked on it by a friend that had the set and had to go out and get my own set to watch the whole thing.  Great show, too bad that Showtime droped it, but guess they didn't know that that they had a good thing.

This show had great one liners and funny too.
Great DVD and great service! Shop here!

I'd just like to take a moment to respond to Drake-by-the-Lake's comments of September 18, 2005, because while they're generally accurate, they're also just plain wrong.  He complains that they show is not scary enough.  He complains about the fact that there are separate agents for killing and reaping when it would be more efficient to have one agent do both deeds.  He talks about how the show holds his interest, and then admits he didn't watch it all the way through.  As he calls himself a movie critic, I respectfully submit that he might want to actually criticize the show for what it is, rather than for not being some other show he wishes it were.  It's not scary.  It's not meant to be.  It's a comedy.  Scary may be good, but the chills he's talking about don't belong in this particular show.  Further, anyone who bothers to think about the whole Reaper system as devised for this show will be able to come up with dozens of ways that it doesn't work, doesn't quite make sense.  But that's okay.  This show does not put forth a theological, philosophical, metaphysical or any other workable system of the afterlife, because that's not what it's about.  This show is not about how we die, or why.  This show is about how we live.  And the observations it makes and questions it asks, while occasionally trite, heavyhanded and clichd, are far more often quite poignant, profound (as far as television goes), and painfully funny.  This show works far more often than not, and has had me laughing and closer to crying than any other show I can think of.  Do yourself a favor and watch both seasons, and then seek out Bryan Fuller's other show, the delightfully whimsical, quite brilliant WONDERFALLS, which was cancelled after only three or four episodes but has all fourteen that were filmed in the DVD set.

Without a doubt this series takes a Dark and enjoyable look at Death. From the pilot this show had me hooked. I bought the first and second series as soon as they were available on DVD.

Mondays were then dedicated to Fox and by the the second series even my wife was hooked. Sometimes the language may have been a bit much for her but the acting and content was Hypnotic. I encourage anyone with an enjoyment of a dark sense of humor to watch. Ellen Muth was a perfect choice for this role, the mix of each of the characters was unique and blended to perfection. It makes you hope that this would be real life and that some answers to death would be explained. First rate.

I picked this show up after reading several reviews, good and bad. For those who are touchy about death, this show isn't for you. But if you are up for a show about death I would choose this one. At 35 bucks its a pretty good deal, I just wish there were subtitles. That might seem unimportant to some but I don't hear so well. But about the people writing one star reviews saying how this show is makes death seem like a joke... We'll actually it sort of does but hey, if you couldn't figure that out by watching commercials or reading reviews this probobly isn't for you.

Dead Like Me is one of the best shows Showtime has ever had. I'm very disappointed that it had been cancelled. We watched the 2nd season first and loved it. Now after watching the 1st season the second makes more sense. We will watch the 2nd again. I highly reccommend buying both seasons and enjoy.

An exceptionally well made and outstanding "television show."  It's great to have the DLM DVD's 'cuz apparently the show itself has passed away.  It's a shame that when such a cut above the rest show comes along there's just not enough people out there who truly appreciate excellent television and that networks, whether the "majors" or the cables, give in so quickly to moving on, usually to more of the same old schlock.  Dead Like Me deserved a better and longer chance to be seen by more and more of those truly dicriminateing viewers who watch and support this sort of television, like "HUFF" and such.  If you ever saw DLM while it was on Showtime and wish for more, well, at least we have the two seasons on DVD.  Humbug to those who let this show go off the air.
One of the best series I've ever seen. Its touching, funny and even insightful

SHOWTIME made a huge mistake in cancelling this brilliantly written show. Not only was the writing so innovative, but it was cast beautifully (if you didn't have an interesting, remarkable face, you didn't get into this series), but the idea was so incredibly unique and original. Compare this series to any vapid "s*it-coms" on Network TV and you'll see.

I didn't know who Ellen Muth (George) was or where she came from, but she's an utterly charming actress with a lot of spunk and grit. I hope she gets cast in movies and TV shows. I want to see more of her. She perfectly grasped a difficult role in which a directionless 18 yr old is killed and suddenly has to deal with Life's (and mostly Death's) huge issues in a hurry. She was just floating through life wasting it when it was taken away in half a heartbeat, now she and the other Reapers are stuck in a terrible Limbo where they must start the mechanics of a terrible freak accident or murder every day.

  The entire casting was perfect and I worked with a PR robot boss like Delores Herbig (as in herbig brown eyes. George changed that to as in herbig fat a$$-my favorite line.) The show was as funny as Cheers,(funniest episode was when George lost her virginity and the guy never called her back) but deep enough in its philosophy of life to make you tear up. I loved the New Age type music score and the stunning photography of Canada. I loved EVERYTHING about this series. Now it's all gone forever. The truly weird thing was that Rebecca Gayheart, who was killed off in Season one, actually was a reaper in real life, having failed to stop at a crosswalk and killing a child.

IF NETWORK TV HAD A BRAIN THEY WOULD BUY UP THESE CANCELLED CABLE SHOWS, CLEAN UP THE LANGUAGE, AND START SHOOTING NEW EPISODES BECAUSE NETWORK TV STINKS AND IS DEVOID OF VERY MUCH CREATIVITY !

I, too, will be cancelling Showtime. They destroyed Queer As Folk with mediocre, cliche' ridden story lines and replaced DLM and QAF with stinkers such as Fat Actress and Weeds.

"Dead Like Me" is brilliantly funny, dark, at times moving, and always interesting.  I can't recommend this show enough to people.  The good news is there's a second season that is almost as good as the first, the bad news is that Showtime cancelled the show and there will be no more episodes.  Still, this show, particularly this season, is just a pleasure to watch.

Dead Like Me season one tells the tale of Georgia Lass, a young girl who is bored with life.  One day she dies (Hit by a toilet seat that fell from the sky) and come to find out, she is a reaper.

I loved this, and I am sadded to learn that Showtime will not do a third season.  Dead Like Me is the only reason I paid for Showtime, and I have revoked my subscription.

If you love a dark humor, then you will love this very wonderful show.

"Dead Like Me" was the ONLY reason I paid the extra $15 a month for Shotime.  It is truly one of the most creative, disturbing, yet inspiring and eye-opening shows I have ever watched.

This series takes a topic most people are afraid to approach (Death) and puts a light-hearted spin on it.  Not only has this show allowed me to probe into myself deeper, made me face my own fears of death, but it has inspired me to live more fully, to cherish every minute, and to believe that perhaps there is hope for a better afterlife other than the heaven/hell scenario that seems to scare us into submission and docility.

"Dead Like Me" woke me up.  I used to go through the motions, just eat, sleep, work....but now I view life as more of an opportunity. That life is really what you make of it.  We can choose to be miserable and bitchy (like the character Joy, Georgia's mother), or we can learn from our thoughts and actions and just try and do the best job we can at whatever our jobs are (like the "Reapers").

I started watching this show because one of my friends said the character "Georgia Lass" reminded her of me.  LOL, how true, how true. After the first episode, I was hooked and still watch the reruns religiously.  :)

The characters are hysterically funny even if they are dealing with a morbid subject.  The whole take on what goes on in life, during death, and after death is refreshing.

To those who didn't 'get it' Open your hearts and minds NOT just your mouths! This show is just what it should be OPEN, HONEST, HEART WARMING, LAUGH TILL YOUR BELLY HURTS, THOUGHT PROVOKING & AND COMPLETELY SATISFYING . You can call them "rip offs"( but get over yourselves)that what makes it endearing, the fact that we can connect the characters and situations with (people real or otherwise,tv characters  ect.) & times makes the impression & touches are hearts & minds. JUST WATCH AND LET GO...ENJOY THE RIDE.Try not to over think the show and you will find you have learned how to think deeper and more real then you ever had. I will be enjoying these two seasons for years. Each time I watch them I get more out of them...Judge for yourselves!  God Bless, D

Looking back at the week rewatching episodes from this series' first season, I can't help but feel bad for the guys behind the show. Here you had perfectly good television with a loyal (i.e. ratings-challenged) following. You also had great material and terrific writing to work with but look what happens. It gets the boot after two seasons. Now, I'm not big into whining but I need to say something here. Axing this show was a big mistake, something right along the lines of cancelling Angel, Firefly and Wonderfalls. Because with a little support and time, the show could've been spectacular. Now contrary to what some believe, this series is very different from Six Feet Under (also seeing its end very soon) despite sharing a similar basic premise (seeing dead people). Both shows are fun and smart, but I've always preferred Dead Like Me because its storyline works better for me.

It is probably too late to try and "save" the series but hey, at least one can always look back at the dvd sets (season 2 for DLM is coming very soon) and enjoy them for what they are, a hilarious and oftentimes serious take on death and the afterlife. I guarantee that you will find the characters (even the, ahem, short lived ones) endearing. You will be thoroughly entertained!

Don't listen to the negative reviews.  If you have a sense of humor and an imagination you will love this show.  It is witty, funny, thoughtful and dramatic all at the same time.  This is definitely NOT a boring show and should not have been canceled by the pay channel that carried it but I digress....

This is a show about a girl (George) who dies in an unusual way and is on her way to becoming a reaper.  Along the way she makes a lot friends but she is not allowed to interact with her family.  When George died she left behind her parents and a sister who misses her terribly.  I would highly recommend this series.

Ditto the negative responses for cliches, wooden dialogue, etc.. I was only able to spend 20 minutes with this snoozer of a show. Showtime let this show die for a good reason. Try six feet under instead.
I bought this because the series is witty, well written and fun to watch. The characters all have great development and you begin liking and relating to them.

well i think that this is a really good show that deffo deserved more than a two season slot.in fact i have to put it along some of my favorite shows of the last decade, i like the way that the story seems to be in no hurry to where its going, and the quirky nature of it all.just my type of stuff...a real alternative feeling, away from mainstream rubbish.

when eightteen year old george went on her lunch break she was hit by a tolit seat and joined the ranks of becomeing a grim reaper now george must reap souls  an hold down a crappy job (DLM) was the best showtime series to date its still hard to belive they ended the series only after two seasons but you can keep the show alive with the dvd.

In the summer of 2003, I read about a new show coming to Showtime called "Dead Like Me" which seemed interesting, but unfortunately I don't have the premium cable channels. So, there I was just waiting for the inevitable release of the DVD set. All I have to say is that it was worth the wait. The writing is mostly well done, though the "George flouts the rules in some way" storyline could've been used for like two episodes before going to more fertile creative ground. The characters are perhaps where the show excels. All of the characters at some point will annoy you, but then something'll happen that'll make you love them. Still, the writers needed to work more on the Daisy Adair character. There was no part of her character that was appealing and there were very little "saving grace" aspects to her. My favorite character would have to be Dolores Herbig, for probably the same reasons as other reviewers here. The DVDs are very nice with good picture. I haven't had a chance to look at the extras, though they do seem a little slim for 14 episodes. My biggest problem with the set is the descriptions for the episodes. Either they allude to something that is barely mentioned like "Reaper Madness" and the "biblical proportions" thing or make the episode sound like an afterschool special like "Business Unfinished" and the "lessons of the afterlife for all."

If you like having all the answers, all the time than DLM is not the show for you. If you like shows that make you think about something in your life, then at least one episode of the season will have you thinking. No matter what, try an episode or two, maybe you'll love it as much as I do.

The pilot episode was decent, and it certainly had great special effects. But I'm afraid that the plot line seemed to limp. The character Roxy was flacid. Rube seemed pretty good as a leader (middle mangagement). Mason has more potential, but sells out.
The series drags along, and has no real momentum. The story lines are lousy, and the season finale was dreadfully pitiful. One of the later episodes in the first season is about the gravelings taking a day off, and the grim reapers having to file paperwork for the souls that have been taken over the time.-It seems like they were already running out of bad ideas, so they came up with another poor one. If anyone here agrees with me in the slightest, I advise to check out Nip/Tuck, or Sopranos, or Six Feet Under, Curb Your Enthusiasm, Seinfeld.-Guaranteed not to be disappointed.

I'm currently enjoying the 2nd (and sadly last) series of DLM on Sky 1. This show is fantastic and original, really the besy show around.

 DLM centres around George, who we meet on the last day of her 18 years of life. But luckily (though she doesn't see it that way) she doesn't pass to the other side, she has been chosen for a special job - a reaper - collecting the souls of people about to die, and sending them to the other side.

 George isn't alone in this, in her area there is a team of 4 other reapers lead by Rube, to help and guide her in her new life...

 DLM really goes the extra mile when we also follow George's parents and younger sister as they try to deal with this bombshell, and move on.

Simply an amazing show: at times serious, funny and shocking, you are always left thrilled.

Pilot (Double length)

Dead Girl Walking

Curious George

Reapercussions

Reaping Havoc

My Room

Reaper Madness

A Cook

Sunday Mornings

Business Unfinished

The Bicycle Thief

Nighthawks

Vacation

Rest in Peace

If you are one of the few who gave this series only one star, I can see why. You really need to view this program with a grain of salt and an open mind. If you are being ultra critical or just plain not up for the idea of "grim reapers", then I can see the disappointment. "Dead Like Me" is great! The funny, ironic situations the characters get into are so clever. It is written well. The waffle haus is just fun, not stupid. The post-it's? that is unique, and there is the whole mystery behind the who gives the list. Oh, and the post-it's only come from Rube. He gets his list of deaths and then transfers them to all the others. Rube is so Mandy Patinkin--dry and witty, very "take it or leave it"--love him. And Mason is a just a quirky burn-out. Love the "drug search at the airport" and the "need sex" episodes! Anyway, it is a crying shame that they cancelled this series!!!!

Having read so many mixed reviews of this show, I wasn't sure exactly what to expect.  After watching the first season, I now feel that this now-cancelled show is better than 99% of the shows on non-cable channels.

Ellen Muth, who really was an unknown coming into this series, does a terrific job as George, a slacker who remains unmotivated even after becoming undead.  While her character initially comes across as abrasive and somewhat annoying, she eventually shows a softer underbelly, especially with regards to the mother and sister she mostly disliked while alive.

Mandy Patinkin is his usual self, someone who many will like while others will hate.  His Rube is the leader of this group of the undead, and Patinkin gives his character an everyman quality that I found endearing.  Of the other supporting cast, Cynthia Stevenson stands out as George's still-grieving mom who also has a difficult younger daughter with whom to deal.  I felt that Rebecca Gayheart was the weak link among the cast, but she thankfully left during the season.

The stories are pretty simple, dealing with the taking of souls.  However, these tales are used to take a look at the life of George and the members of her group.  Happy and sad, funny and depressing, but always entertaining.  I'm shocked that anyone could find this show as unappealing as some do.  I'd recommend it to any fan of quality television, both for its originality and its compelling characters.

I love Dead Like Me and this product is perfect for those of us who don't have Showtime, but have seen and fallen in love with the show at a friends house. I recieved this DVD set as a gift and I love it.

Dead Like Me is a show about Georgia (aka George, Millie, Toilet Seat Girl, Peanut etc) and the experience of her death. George is (was) an 18 year old who, after dropping out of college her first semester moves back in with her parents and kid sister. Upon being nagged by her mother to get a job, George begins clerical work at a place called Happy Time. On her first day working at Happy Time she goes out of the office to grab a quick lunch when she encounters a man on the street who asks her name and touches her when she walks away, then she gets hit in the head with a toilet seat which fell from space and dies... sounds weird but it's well done.

Right after her death George realizes that she has not left the earth, and is confused by this. She ends up meeting some Grim Reapers, Rube being the boss (played by Mandy Patakin), and they explain to her that she is dead and that she is to be a Grim Reaper. Rube explains that when you die and you weren't a good person, nor a bad person you have to become a Reaper for sometime until you fill your Quota of souls. So what George's job as a Reaper is that she must take the souls out of people who are about to die accidential\painful deaths so that that person will feel no pain. Rube gives this particular group of Reapers their assignments daily, which consist of enitials, and address, and an E.T.D. (estimated time of death) and the Reapers are to find this person and take their soul out of their bodies.

You might be wondering how she can walk around the same city she was living in without some people knowing her, this is covered, in this show the dead take on different names to the public (George is Millie) and they look very different to the living.

The show follows George as she gets used to the fact that she is dead, and her coping with the fact that being dead doesn't change the fact that she now needs a place to "live" (which the Reapers show her that she can inhabit the apartments of dead people who no one knew were dead yet), and the fact that she needs to get a real world job (which she happens to go back to Happy Time). The Reapers are all friendly with each other and hang together in a diner.

The show also deals with George's family and how they deal with her loss. Her mom, who never really got along with George is extreamly guilty, her little sister who George always ignored misses her more than anyone, and her dad privatly grieves. George, looking different is able to have somewhat regular encounters with members of her family, and she finds out some family secrets which explain alot of the relationship problems her parents have.

This show is great. It is funny and sad all at once. I guess some would call it dark comedy. The cast is incredibly talented and make the show that much more fun to watch. The DVD set is packaged nicely and the special features are fun.

My current theory on the mysteries of television programming is that all the good shows have left the networks, and they're heading for the premium cable channels. Think about it. NYPD Blue and Angel are gone; West Wing is but a pale shadow of its former self. The Sopranos and Six Feet Under are getting all the critical praise these days.

So it shouldn't have surprised me that premium cable's other show about coping with death is so good. The formula is simple and obvious: who better to approach the issue of one's own mortality than a dead person? In the case of Dead Like Me, death is approached by not one, but several dead people.

Apparently, if you fit certain criteria -- and you fill someone's quota -- upon your death, you're pressed into service as a Grim Reaper. You get a list of deaths for the day, and you take custody of the departed souls until they reach their final destination. As an undead person, explains Rube (Mandy Patinkin in a perfect role), you have "certain rights and privileges." A physical body, for example, and the ability to interact with the living (though the living see you as a different person than you were in life). The Reapers of Dead Like Me are not mystical skeletons; they're -- pardon the pun -- working stiffs. Of course they don't get paid, so they have to either work a day job or find other nefarious ways of paying for such amenities as clothing, food and a home.

Some of this show's best moments deal with such mundane elements as finding a home, keeping a job, or blundering through a get-rich-quick scam. But it really shines when the mix of the mundane and the macabre takes a sudden turn for the serious. In the series pilot, George, our heroine, is suddenly killed by the meteoric landing of Mir's zero-gravity toilet. It's a bizarre situation treated in such a way that it's ridiculously funny. Somehow, Dead Like Me doesn't lose its humorous edge, even as George accompanies Rube to her own autopsy ("The first man to touch my naked body was a coroner.") and her own funeral. If you can laugh at an autopsy, you've begun to insulate yourself from the pain of death; can you laugh at your own autopsy?

This first season is short, with only 14 episodes. In them, George and her family begin coping with her death, but we see that it's a long road. George's Reaper colleagues have been dead a lot longer than she has, and still don't seem to have wrapped up their lives. Daisy is still the same Southen belle actress who had an affair with Clarke Gable on the set of Gone With the Wind. Roxy is still troubled by her death at the hands of the woman who stole her invention: leg-warmers. Mason hasn't learned from a drug-induced attempt to free his mind. And Rube... well, we still don't have Rube's story, apart from the fact that his first car was made in 1898.

It's a huge subject, death. And it's an interesting way to look at death, through the eyes of those who have lost their own lives and see others' deaths every day. So, it's got heavy stuff, but Dead Like Me is the most wickedly funny show currently on TV. True comedy comes from dramatic situations; we laugh when our brains can't cope with the ridiculousness or magnitude of a situation. Drama and comedy are two sides of the same chihuahua, and it's a pity that more TV producers haven't realized that. Dead Like Me blends gravitas with black comedy in ways that are unsubtle, unavoidable, and utterly captivating.

I was truly dissapointed that this show has been cancelled.  it is the only new show i have been able to get really into in a long long time.

I think the characters are wonderful and deep, the stories can be silly, but they always achieve something.  I could watch Mason all day everyday... but thats just me!

I don't understand how crap like the OC can stay on and DLM gets the boot after 2 seasons.  I immediatly cancelled Showtime in protest and am hoping Fox or some other network can pick it up (clean up the language too, I guess) and get it back on the air!

I watched this because the producer claimed it was inspired by ON A PALE HORSE. Do not make the same mistake. There is no resemblance between Anthony's theo-fantasy and this characteristically moronic sitcom about undead slackers.

  Again unlike Anthony, the show remains vague about what really happens to the dead in the evident hope that this is the way to avoid "offending" anyone... no matter how many people the touchy-feely pseudo-theology (a characteristic also displayed by other current "spiritual" shows like Joan of Arcadia) DOES offend.

  I do not have to watch television if I want (which I don't) to hear people who act as though they are unable to utter a sentence without a gutter expletive. As it is, I kept wishing Buffy would show up and dust them all.

Dead Like Me has been one of the best shows i've seen for ages. I won't write a massive review, as most reviews below show just how great it is.

But for some reason, its been canceled! If you like the show, please buy the dvd's from amazon and make sure you sign the petition:

[...]

;-)

After seeing the numerous five stars given for this show, I decided to pick up this series on DVD and see what the hype was about. Boy, did I make a bad decision. As one reviewer pointed out, there were a lot of "rip-offs" from other shows or movies (The lead character reminded me of Daria from the Beavis & Butthead spin-off show). But besides that, a lot of the shows were just plain boring and/or sort of annoying. For example, one of the characters (the blonde who replaces Rebecca Gayheart) is an actress from the 20's that constantly mentions giving oral favors to famous actors in between sets or during meetings when she was alive. C'mon, give me a break. Or some of the situations just weren't explained or didn't make sense. Why put people's E.T.D. on a sticky note? And who was submitting these and why didn't he give more explanation to help out the reapers. Even if this could be explained to me, this just isn't funny or interesting. I could go on with a ton of other stuff that didn't make sense, was annoying or just plain dull but I'll leave it up to you to continue to read the other reviews that didn't give this show five stars and try to make a better decision than me.

What a major disappointment. With the boring and unoriginal storylines, very poorly acted characters, silly settings (a German pancake house with yodeling in the background - what was the point of this and was this suppose to be funny?), etc. Showtime should have passed on this show and maybe see if Lifetime or UPN would pick it up. Teen girls might like this show but beware of the numerous rip-offs in the show - Seven feeling you get when you die (this was in a Simpson's episode where Homer thinks he's going to die), the super annoying boss at work (Office Space, Ferris Buellers Day Off, etc.), on and on. On top of that, there are just way too many logistical and plot holes that make this already poorly written show drop dead bad. I know people are going to say but it's just a show (or no way this can't be true) but when you pay good money to watch or own this show you should be warned up front that a combination of some Bigwigs at Showtime along with a new writer from an Ivy League school doesn't equal success or original writing.

I thought the first season was very compelling and since I don't have showtime, I had to buy the first season on dvd. It was great - one of the best series ever on tv right up there with all the great shows in cable series format. For example: Nikita even though DLM it wasn't all action all the time, in it's own way it was just as good as any other hit cable show. So where's the second season my money is in my hand ready to buy? You too, should want this impressive cable series the second season of this fantastic and highly entertaining 'Dead Like Me'!

I got to see this show by mistake, I am the kind of guy that only watch tv to lighten up, and smile. I believe that live is way too complicated by itself to get back home and see drama/blood etc.

So I only tend to watch sitcoms, I don't enjoy CSI like stuff either. Watched some promos about the show and that they made some fun of afterlife...uhmmm, everyone wants to know something about after life, I knew already that I would not find no answer there, but at least I will have the chance to see other's view of the issue.

Watched the pilot with this thin/strange voiced girl and got shocked/hooked very very badly. Every chapter made you think about the afterlife but was funny at the same time. I even enjoyed more the 2nd season, it is better ellaborated than in the first one, and the cast looked way more integrated.

This series really deserves a third/closing season.

One thing that this show leaves on you is that you only have a live, even if there is an afterlife after all, you only have one chance to live it.

Reading some of the below reviews makes me wonder how blind people are to the depth of DLM.  It's an amazing show, and the only show I've ever been interested enough in to watch every week.  Stereotypical characters? -- Everyone in the world follows a stereotype.  The quality of the show is that the characters are normal people with normal problems.  Some of the scenes dealing with George's family are the most poignant -- especially if one has experienced similar situations in their own life. You can relate to it.  DLM shows the psychological aspects of people and their relationships with each other.  Season 2 is better because it develops some the threads introduced in season 1.  Everyone I've shared DLM with, loves it.  I guess there are some people out there who are unable to appreciate a show that operates on multiple levels because their intellect has been dulled by dumbed-down television.

Where do I start? The terrible writing? The recycled plot lines (ever watch any show or movie ever that features an office environment or ponders the afterlife)? The bad acting? The contrivance embedded in every single episode? The cliches piled upon nauseating cliches? I could spend hours writing about the problems with this show, but I have already wasted enough hours justifying the blind purchase of this horrid dvd set. But my biggest regret is trading it in at a record store- now it will either plague someone else or entertain some cynical, smarmy dummy with zero sensibility.

Dead like me is a show positively brimming over with wasted potential.

They begin with a good concept, that the afterlife is run like a bureaucracy, but grim reapers don't get paid and thus must seek additional employment. This leads to some pretty good scenes, such as Roxy's job as a Meter Maid (always entertaining to watch) and George's job at Happy Time Temp Agency. Of all the different segments, the Happy Time ones are the best-Dolores Herbig, George's boss, is one of those characters who seems nice but along the way constantly reveales incredibly disturbing things about herself. Crystal the Receptionist is always funny, usually nothing more than a glaring pair of eyes staring across the reception desk.

The other segments of the show not directly involved in reaping, the interaction of George's sister Reggie and her mother Joy, are a pain to watch. They litterally do nothing but bicker with one another episode after episode-after all this fighting, one presumes, these segments must eventually lead to something, have some purpose, right? You would think so, but they don't. They have no point and go nowhere. You could excise these segments from the show entirely and it would be the better for it.

Finally we come to the heart of the show, which deals with the actual reaping of souls. These segments could have been best of all; indeed, they could have made this show a real gem but the writers dropped the ball on this one, too. Firstly, the gravelings. These little creatures supposedly run around causing accidents that kill people, but these creatures are the show's greatest flaw. Not only do they cause some really ludicrous death scenes, but they completely ruin the mystery and randomness of death in favor of a few cheap sight gags. Secondly, the plot holes: they establish right off the bat that the undead reapers look different to the living so they won't be recognized. George's undead persona, Millie, looks like a crack whore. But they continually forget this very important plot point again and again. They never mention their undead appearances after the first few episodes. This show could have been very good, it certainly has some good moments, but unfortunately it is as stiff and lifeless as its subject matter.

When you watch a series from a cable network (HBO, Showtime, etc.) you expect good quality writing, originality and a somewhat entertaining show. With Dead Like Me, you don't get any of these things. But hear me out - First of all, this series is definitely geared towards girls between the ages of 17-20 (trust me on this). But regardless of this, there were so many clichs, unoriginal jokes, and just boring writing that this series was very hard to watch.

On top of the awful writing, the characters were incredibly annoying, shallow and just hard to relate or even care for in this show. As one reviewer stated, all your typical characters are in this show - Jaded, don't smile, fish-out-of-water teen girl, your foreigner (not the band) lad, the cheesy sex-pot, cheating husband, etc...

The jokes and storylines were either so boring, ripped off from something else (especially American Beauty for the mother, father and little sister storyline), or so filled with plot holes that you spent more time getting annoyed by this than actually enjoying the show. For example:  Girls that have boy names, thinking the word "moist" is pornographic or gross, main character narrating to the viewer (I never understood this technique and it sort of  questions the viewer's intelligence - can you say "Malcolm In The Middle"),  etc.

I give Showtime credit for taking a chance on this show (maybe trying to compete with HBO's Six Feet Under) but there are too many plot and logistical flaws and holes for the idea of this show. Showtime should have backed out of this project or at least hired better writers.

I love Dead Like Me and this product is perfect for those of us who don't have Showtime, but have seen and fallen in love with the show at a friends house. I recieved this DVD set as a gift and I love it.

(estimated time of death) and the Reapers are to find this person and take their soul out of their bodies.
