This show is great. It is funny and sad all at once. I guess some would call it dark comedy. The cast is incredibly talented and make the show that much more fun to watch. The DVD set is packaged nicely and the special features are fun.

The characters are rich and complex, the writing is amazing, and the shots and visuals are mind-boggling. You really cannot compare this show to Six Feet Under. To me, Six Feet Under is like a Soap Opera full of characters I could care less about.  All of the characters and situation in Dead Like Me are right on.

I have watched this DVD so many times it is scary!  I'm hooked, my sister and brother in law are hooked, and all the friends I have showed it to are hooked.  One problem - they really have some chutzpah to have almost an entire episode be flashbacks when they hadn't even been on for a season.  Also, some of the rules of the grim reapers that they talk about in the first episode don't hold up as the show goes on. Surprising and Shocking!

The "other" dead show?  What a perverse perspective.  In my opinion, this is easily the best series I have watched.  It works on every level -  it is smart, poignant, funny, sad, profound, unpredictable, and amazingly entertaining.  The actors and actresses are very well cast, and the plots are never boring.  The characters are very believable, and the dry, smart humor never goes into the predictable cliches that have become the staple of most sitcoms.

This show is so funny and moving, often at the same time, it becomes difficult to even watch other shows.  It also dances along the delicate line of having a message without being preachy.  The dialogue is superb, spoken with perfect timing by excellent actors.  Callum Blue and Ellen Muth could make an ill-humored mailbox laugh, although that could probably said to a lesser degree about all the actors in the show.

If you are sick of bland, derivative, childish sitcoms, then get this DVD.  I can not imagine anyone being disappointed in it.

This is an addendum to my initial review.  Recently, I had someone visit from Florida who I wanted to show this series to.  She showed absolutely no interest in it, despite my telling her how incredible this series was. She was very reluctant to watch even one show, but I knew she would like it so I persisted in trying.  Eventually I managed to get her to watch an episode.  After that, whenever she would come over she would ask to see more and each night would watch a couple of episodes until it was time to leave.  When she finally went back to Florida she said she was going to buy the DVD set for herself.  She said she loved the show and found the characters all very likeable and believable, and enjoyed the interactions between them very much.  This show is so good one has no doubt that people will like it.  I never had any at all, it was just a matter of getting her to watch one episode.

Even if you have never seen it - and you hear all your friends and people on the radio talk about it - go and get it - you will not be disappointed.

Now lets look forward for when season 2 is on DVD

They cancelled Dead Like Me. I really don't know why for some silly cop drama I heard. But this series is fantastic its a great dark comedy and nothing like HBO's Six Feet Under which was a drama. I watched the second season and had to get the first season and it was fantastic. I hope some other network picks up Dead like me because frankly this was the only reason i was keeping showtime.

This show is one of the few shows that are even worth watching. I had never heard of this show before the first season ended. When I did I immediatly bought the DVD and could not turn it off. I had to see every episode. I would highly recommend this series to anyone who has a morbid fear of death. This show uses dark humor to explain that while life is great and all eventually, the Grim Reaper catches up with us. The good thing is that there is something better on the other side. The story of our lives does not end with death it simply changes scenes.
If you are looking for a unique and entertaing television show this is it. Don't be surpised if you have to watch the whole season in one sitting!

This is one of those shows that you wish you would have known about sooner. You definitely won't be disappointed. Not only is the show well written and well acted, but it's also fresh and interesting. It's one of the bright spots on the channel line up - especially in a time like this where most of our shows are "reality" based or candy coated.

I loved it. Can't wait for more episodes.

This show is awsome, i got hooked when i was channel surfing one sunday and immediatly bought the first season so i could catch up.  Showtime's cancellation after season two is devestating!  There is an online petition to support reinstating this wonderful show-check showtimes message board for DLM to find the web adress...

Clever, witty, and thought provoking.

It brought me back to watching a series, my whole family and all my friends love it.

A terrible shame that Showtime is cancelling this, I have the DVD set and am patiently waiting for the second season to come out.

This is a fresh comedy about afterlife. This is a comedy/drama...and ya, theres sad moments. Though the writing and the plot itself are strong, a lead of great characterization is what makes Dead Like Me work out well. This is not far from being a masterpiece.

Now, lets just hope that life after death is this funny!

My husband bought this series for me for my birthday, and I LOVE IT!  I had never seen the show, and when he told me about it I was a little wary of it,b ut I gave it a shot anyway.

This is without a doubt one of the funniest shows I have ever seen, and is definitely my favorite.  The humor is so off key and sarcastic, but that's just what I like.

Okay, I watched the entire 1st season in 4 days.  I don't believe in the everafter but if it's out there, I hope it's like that.  The situations are fascinating and the actress that plays Georgia is actually very good at being mundane in expression.  Every character reveals things about themselves as the shows progress and I think it's that that draws you in and fascinates you.  They are such an eclectic group of people you know there is no other possible situation that would have drawn them together except for something as unusual as this.

So, go ahead and blow the 50 bucks for the box set.  You'll laugh, you'll probably cry a little, and perhaps you'll wonder.  But you will definately be entertained.  :)

"There's nothing like your own death to put your life into perspective."

I really like this series. It's a well written (well acted) show about the lighter side of death. Or "life after life." Is there an afterlife? For these reapers, there is. They become cosmic temps, taking souls (those who's time has come) until they too can move on....eventually (or so they hope). Somehow, they manage to make this more funny than morbid. Though the concept seems pretty depressing, it's both sad at times, and incredibly amusing. That's a great combination to me. Laughter thru misty eyes. Kind of makes you appreciate those in your life that are important. And serves as a not-so-subtle reminder not to take them for granted. So far, only 2 seasons have been made (and only one of those available on dvd to date) and no word as of yet about a 3rd season. (I hope they make a 3rd season!)

A friend once told me that he was creeped out whenever an episode of "The Twilight Zone" featured a ventriloquist's dummy. Those episodes never impressed me, but recently I got chills watching an old episode about a toy telephone.

You can never tell what's going to strike a chord and resonate with a particular person. "Dead Like Me" is not for everyone. Some people will hate it. Others just won't "get" it. It's too bad, really, because they're missing out on something truly wonderful.

18-year-old Georgia (George) Lass, deceased, has a new job: collector of souls of the newly departed--a grim reaper, if you prefer. She doesn't want to be a reaper. She doesn't know how to be a reaper. She gets on-the-job training. What she learns about, mostly, is life.

In life, George was too cool to care about anything. In death, she learns to care, in ways that are funny and sad together. The result is the most consistently moving television show I've ever seen. At the end of each episode, when the credits appear, I find myself shaking my head and muttering, "What a GREAT show!"

The language and some visuals are too harsh for young children. The show contains a lot of adult subject matter--no, not like cable porn--rather, like parents struggling over how to cope with an emotionally troubled 11-year-old daughter. Material for genuinely mature audiences. Very rare, that.

Not for everyone, but I couldn't recommend it more highly. What a GREAT show.

My partner and friends think I'm perverse, but I love Dead Like Me and find every episode hilarious.  I suppose one could take it seriously and then perhaps be sad or offended, but it would be pretty tough to actually think that someone could be killed by a toilet seat falling from space or that Death has minions who go around taking the souls of people whose names are doled out to them on Post-It notes.

Yet Dead Like Me does work as a "straight" plot (more or less) and that's one of the things I love about it. The fact that the shows cast and crew offer this stuff up with a straight face just makes it all the more funny.  And it's what gives the characters enough depth and credibility to make the viewer care about them. From the lead "reaper," Georgia, to her dweeb mother, Joy, to her fellow reaper, the former actress Daisy, the characters are both unique and believeable.

My favorite is Delores Herbig, Georgia's boss at Happy Time Employment Agency. Check out the episode where George visits Delores at her apartment. Even though it's a studio, Delores proudly shows George around the place, stopping at the "scrapbooking" area and showing her the cat's "feeding station."  The satire rolls down the walls.  And some of the other character's at Happy Time are also hilarious, like the creepy receptionist, Crystal.  Trust me, you will choke with laughter.

After the unwanted demise of Buffy the Vampire Slayer as a primetime television phenomenon...many fans needed some place to go.  Believe it or not, a large group of them went to the quirky, poignant Showtime smash, Dead Like Me.

The previous review did an excellent job in detailing the plot so I won't go into that.  I will, however, talk about the impact the show had on me.

Personally, I am afraid of death, as many people probably are.  The Bible talks about the same ideas that are present in the show, that your soul is removed before you feel any pain, so that death isn't...well, painful.  It's comforting to see this in a show.

Outside of that, this show astounds me every time I watch it.  When Season 1 had aired on Showtime, I didn't get to see the entire thing but I knew I wanted it when it came out on DVD.  I finally bought it, watched the entire thing (sometimes episodes twice in a row before moving on) and I just couldn't get enough.

Ellen Muth's portrayal of George is jaw-dropping.  She so adequately expresses her lack of caring, her sarcasm, her wit, and her internal beauty in every episode.  She truly carries the show in many ways none of the other actors could if they were the lead.  I love finding out more about George, and I get miffed if something happens to her or someone upsets her.  I always find myself siding with her.

In the beginning, Rube seems a nice paternal character but as the show progresses...I find myself very annoyed with him and above all else I would prefer to see him get what's coming to him.

The only other character that pulls any thoughts out of me is Daisy.  I find it amusing the amount of crap she puts the others through, and where her head exactly is that she cares as little as she does.  Like she is still unwilling to accept her position as a reaper.  She is just as indignant as George, constantly trying to push the envelope...but she always has this air of..."I am better than you" that George (thankfully) doesn't have.  It's frustrating to watch.

Simply put, this show is AMAZING!  And the best way to bring it back to earth is George's family.  Their lives are normal, everyday, where George's are not.  It's a nice contrast, and it's interesting to see Reggie's development as a character.  Joy pissed me off in the beginning but I am growing constantly more fond of her, just to have it ripped away by another thing she's said to George in the past.  It's all so...real, so riveting.  I can't get enough of the show.  I really can't.

Being an HBO series lover, and not having Shotime, I rented this set. It was so true in many areas example in that George's mother is needs serious counciling. She actually didn't love her daughter.  Reggie pulls through with the feeling of loss more than Mom. I really thought I would dislike this series and got hooked to the point that I want to get the set to own. I haven't seen the 2nd season but I hear that "lesson learned" concept isn't apparent in season 2. Great acting! It's weird seeing Jasmine Guy play like a Wanda Sykes character.

  In no way is this as good as many HBO series' ie: "Sopranos", "Deadwood" ect. but is very entertaining and makes you think..."what if?"

funny look at death, as if it's appropriate. anyhoo, I've heard about this show because we don't have showtime. I borrowed a friend's copy and liked it.

Too bad that the show's creator left the show for creative reasons. He apparently had fought Showtime because they wanted the show to be more like 'Touched By An Angel' (happy endings, lesson learned, etc).

After Bryan Fuller left, the storyline of George's father being Gay was completely changed among other things. You'll notice episode 1 when her father hugs the other guy in George's funeral. You'll also notice that after episode 5 or so the tone/direction of the show changed.

anyhoo, the show is still good, funny. thumbs up!

I'd heard about this series, so I checked it out and discovered I liked it.  In the affirmative, like any good dram-edy, or co-ma, (1) the characers are witty, (2) the story-line is interesting, and (3) the situations dance on the pin head of a needle.  But, what really makes this show worth watching is (4) George (Ellen Muth) dealing with her afterlife and family and (5) how her family copes with her death as individuals and as a family.  A good supporting cast and sub-plots help round out why I like this show.  In the negative, (1) this is an "R"-rated show dealing with sensitive issues and questioning various belief systems: death, the afterlife, ghosts/spirits, good/evil, etc.  I have no problem with sensitive issues or belief questioning, what I don't like is (2) the abundant use of profanity; and (3) some loose ends encountered in the main and sub plots.  Hopefully, in regards to the loose ends, the second season will take care of them.  As for the rest, I hope the language gets cleaned up.  Overall, this is an "R" show for language and thematic content, so treat it accordingly, especially, if you have young family members.  Otherwise, if you're looking for a nice piece of make-believe/fluff with foul-language, tinged with a touch of sadness, then enjoy this entertaining series.

This show started out so great, with a premise that somewhat odd and unbelievable ended up working, mostly. The problem I have with this show is that it has too many leads into plot conflicts that are never resolved, especially her fathers groping of the guy at her funeral and the subsequent phone calls, etc. I can't wait to catch the second season and hopefully tie up some of these loose plot strings.

For those of you who are missing HBO's "6 Feet Under" this might be your cup of tea.  Don't be mislead though.  It is completely on the opposite end of the spectrum of immortality.  I have really enjoyed the show, but my husband took a few episodes to get hooked.  Enjoy

This is a fresh take on an old concept: the afterlife is run by an inept bureaucracy, so when you die, wackiness ensues. You've seen it before in "Beetlejuice" and "Heaven Can Wait". Which is not to say that "Dead Like Me" is a ripoff of those movies -- it does have its own ideas. The most important of these is that the dead souls drafted as "Reapers" don't get paid, and have to earn a living (one of many such ironies) in various low-profile, and therefore low-paid jobs. It's amusing, and well-acted, but after a while you sort of wonder why George and her team never really have to deal with really nasty, unpleasant death. Or you just suspend all criticalness, get entertained for an hour, but don't really get anything out of it.
Dead Like Me has the best dry and sarcastic humor one can handle. It reminds me alot of myself. So if you enjoy saying what you really think inside your head you will think this series is funny.

Dead Like Me is one of those shows that is funny, sad, witty and powerful all at once. The cast fits together like pieces of a puzzle and all of the characters are believable and enjoyable to watch.

This series takes a unique approach to the afterlife ... where Grim Reapers exist to "pop" one's soul before they come to a painful untimely end. The show wisely avoids religious issues, instead it focuses on the characters and the situations that they are presented with.

I would definitely recommend this set of DVDs ... and I wuld also recommend playing the pilot episode with the commentary track on ... which features most of the main cast discussing the episode, the series in general et al.

"Dead Like Me" is filmed in Vancouver, Canada, set in Seattle, WA.

I had seen a few episodes here and there on the movie network and was instantly hooked.  Once getting the DVD set, the show made so much more sense to watch in order and see how George's life evolved from living.

This is a definite must have for those interested in witty sarcasms and don't want to take life to seriously.  Too many shows these days leave you feeling empty and depressed as the credits roll - not here.

Once in awhile, it's nice to laugh about something that's usually serious and depressing.  It gives a true meaning to live life to it's fullest.

I'm currently watching Season 2 and it gets even better! Trust me, you won't be disappointed! A lot more substance and character developement ensues. :)

I saw the commercial for this show quite some time ago and thought it looked really good. I don't get Showtime and I couldn't watch it so I forgot about it. Then while I was in the video store I saw it and remembered it and thought I had to get it. So I rented the first 2 disks and eminently fell in love. This show is addicting! I bought it soon after and watched the rest of the episodes in a little over a week and a half. This show is really funny and just really good! The extras for this set are pretty cool and the packaging is makes for a really cool look as well. I recommend this for everyone who's not uptight about death. Watch It!

I don't have showtime and I bought this because I heard it was an excellent show and it seemed like something I would enjoy watching.  I am very happy that I bought it.  Georgia is an 18 year old loner forced to find a job.  She is very unahppy with her life.  On her 35 minute lunch hour she is hot by the toilet seat of a soviet spacestation.  One of the many humourous deaths in the show.  And she enters the new world of being a grim reaper.  Which is a "public service" by the way.

Among the reapers are Rube, who loves food to the point of obsession and is the father figure guy.  There is the brit, Mason who is a drug addict and has no qualms with stealing from the dead.  There is Daisy, who replaces a reaper friend of Georgia's  Daisy is a stuck up southern belle who talks about "blowing" varius famous me all the time.  There are a few more interesting character, such as the gravelings, who set death into motion and can only be seen by the undead out of the corner of their eyes.

Georgia has a hard time coping with her death and other emotions.  Among her adventures are trying to go home again, saving the lives of people she's supposed to take the souls from (leading to harsh consequences), finding a day job, and quitting her day job.)

To those unsure, it's a mixture of comedy, black comedy and drama.  It can make you laugh and then get really serious and make you think.  One of best shows on tv now!

How could you NOT like a show whose main character, George, dies in the first episode after being struck by a flaming toilet seat from space?

The sheer hilarity of that opening episode ensues as George and her fellow Grim Reapers are faced with the delicate task of saving the souls of the soon-to-be-dead while at the same time dealing with their own personal after-life issues and fears.

Like Six Feet Under (its more cerebral counterpart on HBO) the characters interact with their dead counterparts to examine and, in some cases, resolve their own issues, and the writing and execution/acting are superb in every episode.

This is definitely not one to share with the kids, though.  The language in this series and the themes are adults-only, so watch blissfully after you've tucked the kids in for the night.  This is a great deal and you will not regret the purchase.

First of all, this is a great series from Showtime!  Despite the title of Dead Like Me, these characters are anything but dead.  The wonderful cast of DLM brings these people to life and makes you feel you know them already as one of your friends.  The show's not just about death, but life and how to live it while you can.  There are life lessons to be learned and lots of fun---and reeping---to be had for all.  There's a twisted plot of comedy and drama and character depth/story wrapped with a bow of sarcastic humor that just can't be denied.  The show is well worth watching and the DVD series set is worth every penny!  It's already season two (Showtime, Sundays @9pm central), so buy the first season and start watching today!
Ellen Muth brings me so into the show that it seems like it could really happen.

George Lass ( Ellen Muth) is an 18 year old girl with no ambition in life. She still lives at home with her parents, and dropped out of college after half a semester. Her mother wants her to make more of her life, and forces George to find a job. Soon George manages to find a job as a file clerk, only to be killed on her lunch break by a falling toilet seat from a space station that exploded. George is not allowed to move on to the afterlife and is forced to become a grim reaper that takes the souls of the living just before they pass over. She is slowly broken into the business by the lead reaper Rube (Mandy Patkin)and is given advice from fellow reapers at a local waffle house that the group meets at everyday to receive their assignments. But, just when George thought that things could not get any worse, she soon discovers that being a reaper does not entitle her to a free ride. She is forced to find a day job in between reaps, a place to stay, and learn all the things about life that she never knew when she was alive.

Right off the bat I would like to say that Dead Like Me is probably one of the most addictive, well written, and funniest shows on television today. There have been films and television shows that concentrate on the afterlife before. However, Dead Like Me takes an original apporach to the subject. The show not only focuses on George and her fellow reapers taking people's souls before they pass over, but on their daily lives in between reaps as well. The reapers are forced to get day jobs and find places to stay. The most ironic thing about the show is that George is forced to take care of herself and learns more about life when she is dead, then she did when she was alive. Another aspect of the show that I like, is the fact that the appearances of the reapers are changed to the world around them, to keep the reapers from being recognized by people that they knew when they were alive. This plays into the other focus of the show which is on George's disfunctional family and how they handle life after George passed on.

Overall Dead Like Me is an amazing show, and I guarantee that once you start watching you will not want to stop. It usually takes me at least a week to go through a full season on DVD, but I went through all 14 episodes of Dead Like Me in just two days. The writing, performances, and non stop laughs drag you in and keep you there.

A solid 5 stars...

I am sure the people at Showtime knew what they were doing when they scheduled "Dead Like Me" to start when HBO's "Six Feet Under" was over, because the two shows are certainly complementary.  However, while the deaths that begin each episode of "Six Feet Under" have their moments in terms of being rather weird (my favorite was the woman convinced it was the Rapture when she saw the a bunch of helium filled inflatable dolls floating away), they do not have the Rube Goldberg quality of what the gravelings can set in motion in "Dead Like Me."

The idea of the afterlife created by Bryan Fuller, who also created the similarly quirky Wonderfalls," is that right before you die you soul is taken from your body by a Grim Reaper.  Although they are replete in the opening title sequence these are not Grim Reapers as in figures in black hood carrying scythes.  In fact, they look like regular folk, although not the regular folk they were when they were alive now that they are a peculiar variety of undead.  We learn the rules of the game along with young Georgia Lass (Ellen Muth), an 18-year-old sourpuss called George.  Having decided to forego the college experience George has been sent out into the world to find a job and during lunch she is passed on the street by a strange man who touches her.  We see a light passing from her to him and within seconds a toilet seat from a disintegrating Russian space station strikes her dead.

George is surprised to see herself looking at the big hole in the ground where she had been standing a moment ago and even more surprised to be informed that she is now a Grim Reaper.  This task is done by Rube (Mandy Patinkin), who is in charge of a cadre of Reapers in this particular town.  This includes Mason (Callum Blue), an English bloke who has figured out that you cannot overdose when you are already dead so indulge in drugs to your heart's contextt; Roxy (Jasmine Guy), a meter maid for the police department with ample attitude to spare; and, at first,  Betty Rhomer (Rebecca Gayheart), a former beauty queen who is ready to move on to the next level.  We are not quite sure what that is, because while Grim Reapers get to release souls and head them in the right direction (bright lights that assume various pleasing shapes), they really do not know what the final destination is really like for the dead.

Of course, in the early episodes of the series George is not happy with being dead and not exactly thrilled with a job when she is given a post-it note with a name, address and E.T.D. (estimated time of death) so she can go reap a soul.  The latter is taken care of when she gets a couple of hard lessons about what happens when she does not (your form in the afterlife is not how you look at the moment of death, but at the moment that your soul is reaped, so it is something you would want to have done before the autopsy).  The former is more difficult, because trying to reconnect with her life from beyond the grave is hampered by the fact that she looks different (to everyone else) and she cannot say anything that would convince anyone who knew her before that she was still around.

One of the strengths of this quirky series is that we do not ignore the family that Georgia has left behind as her mother (Cynthia Stevenson), little sister (Britt McKillip), and father (Greg Kean) try to deal with moving on after her death.  Watching the Lass family disintegrate is almost a show within the show, capable of standing on its own, because their interaction with Georgia the Grim Reaper is infrequent and usually something indirect.  We are as interested in what is going to happen to Joy and Reggie (and J.D. rather than Clancy) as we are to Georgia and her friends.

Another thing that makes "Dead Like Me" work is the actual friendship that springs up between George and Dolores Herbig (Christine Willes).  Now known as Millie, George ends up going back to work at Happy Time, the employment agency that she was taking a lunch break from when the sky fell on her head (even when you are undead a girl has to eat).  Dolores is extremely annoying, but "Millie" pretends to play along so long that she actually starts playing along with Dolores' weltanschauung.

The cherry on top with this show is Mandy Patinkin as Rube, who finally has a role in which he can say pretty much anything he wants, especially when it comes to what he is having for breakfast and how it is cooked.  I like the way he calls George "Peanut" all the time as he imparts to her the facts of being undead.  I also like the way Roxy gets mad at people who tear up their tickets, the moments of conscious that Mason has when doing his job, and the way Reggie honors the memory of her sister.  But then it is a well- established fact that I like quirky.

Joining the cast during this first season is another Grim Reaper, Daisy Adair (Laura Harris), an actress who had a role in "Gone With the Wind" and makes no bones about how she got the gig before she died.  She and George become roommates just to cause further trouble for our heroine (and her frog) and is most definitely the character who rubs me the wrong way.  But in the end I have to say that the only thing about "Dead Like Me" that really bothers me is that the post-it notes only have the first initial of the person who is destined to die.  You cannot tell a person's gender from just an initial.

The clerk in our local video store told me about this series, and I have to admit it's addictive.  Dead Like Me has all the ingredients of a successful non-traditional series: great acting, fascinating individual characters, fast-moving scenes, likeable but complex lead characters, and an offbeat premise.  Selecting a new episode is like looking forward to a reunion with old friends.  So I'd enthusiastically recommend this series to anyone who wants to escape from restrictive, me-too network programming.

Reapers are people who have died but are not ready to move to the ultimate heavenly bliss. Apparently others are, because some of the newly dead get to ascend filmy staircases that presumably lead to better ends.  While waiting to move on, reapers are assigned a quota of souls to pull from bodies of people who have just died.

Rube, played perfectly by Mandy Patinkin, gets names delivered in an envelope, slid under his door. He distributes assignments on yellow post-it notes.  He's a combination of coach, father-figure and boss: kind but tough. His crew (as others noted already) includes an irreverent English druggie, a former actress, a cynical meter maid and of course George, the 18-year-old with an attitude.

Two aspects of the show stopped me from awarding Dead Like Me five stars. First, as others have noted, the show's premise contains inherent contradictions. Reapers have physical bodies that digest food, but presumably they don't age. Reapers travel, drive cars, get apartments and take jobs, but where do they get documents and licenses?  And if they hang around for years, presumably they'd grow in knowledge and wisdom.  And as a career consultant, I resist the notion of afterlife as a series of dreary day jobs.  If the Reapers maintain their pre-death attitudes, they'll outgrow those jobs, become overqualified and even get promoted in spite of themselves.

Second, Dead Like Me inevitably reminds viewers of other shows.  There's an obvious comparison to Six Feet Under, where the dead occasionally leap to life to send a message to the Fisher family.  The coffee shop scenes evoke memories of Seinfeld and of course Sex and the City. And hovering over the series is the ghost of Charlie's Angels, where a kindly man dishes out assignments to an unlikely crew.

To some extent, you can enjoy the comparisons as satire. Sex and the City had an over-the-top publication party; Dead Like Me, an over-the-top employee farewell party.  Charlie's Angels were beautiful obedient young women; this crew is...well, different.
Most of the characters in Dead Like Me seem deliberately overdrawn, especially Dolores, George's employer, and Reggie, George's younger sister. But the show takes away its own satiric edge by allowing us to see a sympathetic side of each character. Dolores crumples when her cat gets sick. Roxy mourns her dance career. And we learn that Daisy was sadly lonely in her former life.

Unlike some reviewers, I enjoyed the scenes with George's own family. They're more complex than we first realize and it's hard to categorize them as "good" or "bad."  And it's more fascinating to watch the worlds of the dead and the living come together, rather than stay within the stifling world of the dead.

Despite these reservations, I'll be first in line to watch Season 2 on DVD...hopefully soon.

I don't buy television series' to keep in my DVD collection. Especially series that have just been released after their first season. I don't own any Buffy the Vampire Slayer DVDs (although the show has some great acting and dialogue), nor do I own Six Feet Under or The Sopranos or any other form of long term television viewing. So what makes this one so different?

Simply put: everything!

In a time where most of what we see and understand comes through that little lighted box with a remote control near-at-hand, it is refreshing to see something different. Something unlike what Hollywood would normally put out there. I can almost hear the arguments against this show before it was released (probably similar arguments that got Wonder Falls cancelled...another excellent show with the same production crew, so I understand). "Death! Who wants to hear about the afterlife of an 18 year old girl?!" and "This family is too dysfunctional!" and "Comedy. We need more comedy!" Let's hope some do-gooder never get's his/her hands on this excellent story concept and tries to change it to a light-hearted, feel-good series or some other ridiculously overdone theme.

So what is this series about? The focus is on Georgia "George" Lass, played perfectly by Ellen Muth. She's like millions of other post-highschool graduates out there; she has no idea what she wants to do with her life, or whether she wants to do anything at all. Her mother, Joy (Cynthia Stevenson), is fed up with her daughter's attitude and forces her out of bed one fateful morning with harsh words and orders for her to "find a job and become a productive member of society." Little does George's mother know, but these harsh words will be the last she ever speaks to her eldest daughter. On George's first day in the workforce, she takes a lunch break and, as she stand on a street corner, gets snuffed out by a zero-G toilet seat that comes crashing into our atmosphere from the disintegrating Mir space station. But before she's killed, a nice black man asks her name and touches her on the back ever so slightly. George has just been Reaped. The toilet seat kills her, but her soul lives on. Rube (Mandy Patinkin) greets her as her new boss. George is to become a Grim Reaper, taking souls from the lives of those that are about to be violently ended.

The irony is smackingly wonderful: a young girl who couldn't have cared less about her own life only moments before is now in charge of the end of lives of god knows how many people. Leaving behind her family is tough, though. And it is poignantly portrayed without getting heavy-handed in the dialogue department. Her mother retreats into herself and becomes an angry woman who likes very little. George's kid sister, Reggie (Britt McKillip), tries to contact George in the afterlife by acting out (she steals toilet seats from her school, uses a Ouji board on top of her own toilet seat in an effort to hear anything coming from the `beyond', and collects dead things like birds). George's father, Clancy Lass (Greg Kean), has an affair with one of his graduate students.

What George hadn't anticipated either was the fact that her life has/had actual meaning. She witnesses her family falling apart but is unable to do anything about it. She also has to work a regular job now (Reapers don't get paid by some surreal agency), as well as do the reaping assignments handed out to her by Rube.

Within this little grouping of Reapers are some outstanding personalities, too. Callum Blue plays Mason, a Reaper who died while drilling a hole into his head in the 1960's in an attempt to reach "the ultimate high." He'll do anything not to work, including stealing from those who he reaps and carrying "illegals in his bottom." Jasmine Guy plays Roxy, a tough and roughshod Reaper who doesn't take anything from anyone. She'd been murdered over money. No wonder she wants to be cop. Laura Harris plays Daisy Adair, a pretty, young actress who knew and had sex with almost all the early movie stars. She's been around the block, trying to find love and acceptance. It's a funny and sad character that comes barreling off the screen.

The thing that'll pull you into this series is the dialogue and the characters. The death of an 18 year old girl and her subsequent enlistment into Reaper-ville can sound rather heavy. And it is. But the writers let that seep into the story and don't force it upon us (not an easy thing to do). The comedy is spot on and never slapstick or inappropriate. I let my teenagers watch a couple of the series and they were laughing out loud many times, and reaching for tissues at the more poignant moments; a testament to a great show if ever there was one (being able to hold the attention of the instant gratification age).

I cannot recommend this series highly enough. I pray that Showtime keeps getting the go-ahead to continue the show. So far, season 2 has been outstanding too. Bravo!
Tongue-in-cheek dry humor with a twist...  don't miss it!

It amazes me how universal the praise is for this show. I wonder if I even saw the same show as everyone else, because the show I saw was a disappointing collection of cliched dialog, stock characters and a plot that felt so contrived I just couldn't get into it.

Just so you know where I am coming from, my favorite TV shows of the moment are 'Aqua Teen Hunger Force', 'Da Ali G Show', 'Six Feet Under', 'Strangers With Candy', 'My So Called Life' and 'Curb Your Enthusiasm'. Compared to those shows, 'Dead Like Me' is quite simply mediocre.

The characters are cliched beyond belief...you have the gruff, man of few words(played by Mandy Patinkin), you have your sassy black woman (Jasmine Guy), wacky idiosynchratic english accented 20-something man, and your sullen 18 year old. Really nothing new here at all as far as character types.

The dialog is even worse. Frequent voiceovers are provided to describe things we can see with our own eyes.  Conversations between characters are awkward in a badly directed way, rather than in a 'this is how people really speak' way. And, in my opinion the actors are all overacting their parts. Worst of all, conversations were frequently accompanied by a soundtrack as if the producers lacked confidence in the power of the dialog to stand on its own.

Perhaps worst of all, I just found the entire concept of the show to be annoying. I can enjoy fantasy scenarios (like Firefly), but this one is just too far fetched and idiotic. If someone has already died, I'm not sure I understand why it is so crucial that they earn money to eat? Are they going to starve and die -- again? I accept plot holes, but this show had so many illogical plot contrivances that I just could not accept the entire concept of the show.

The show seems to have its devoted followers, but let my opinion be a warning that this show is NOT universally loved by all who see it.

I purchased this series, knowing nothing about it other than reading the rave reviews here on Amazon.  Thanks everyone!

A couple of reviewers said things like "buy this if you liked Buffy" which is a comment sure to get my attention.  But the only similarity is that they are both wonderfully written and acted shows.  This is poignant drama, with a touch of humour, and whilst the premise is a fantasy, it is a fantasy dealing with some very real issues (okay, maybe a few surreal ones too).  In part the series is about the ways in which people and families deal with death, but at its core it is a hopeful and positive story with characters you come to care a lot about, especially the main character brilliantly played by Ellen Muth.

My wife occasionly gets exasperated by my habit of buying DVDs almost sight unseen.  And yet now, this is her favourite TV show (this will get me points back for some of the duds I've wasted money on!).  Our teenage children also enjoy it immensely (it has some language and themes that might worry some parents, but in my opinion it is overall a positive experience even for younger teens).  I'm just surprised it ever got put on TV - it seems much too intelligent to survive in the current reality-schlock environment.

After catching this series a couple of times I was hooked.  I love the dark, often side splitting humor, not to mention the unique ways death comes knocking....

Wonderful - had to get the DVD to watch this at my leisure and to share with friends!

Almost forgot to mention, there are "little life lessons" mixed in with each story.... just a bit of something to ponder that adds to and makes this show work so well!

A very good Chicago friend (Hi, David!) recommended this boxed set to us, saying that we would enjoy the program, but he kept his fingers crossed because, well, it is not automatically the kind of show you'd recommend to just everyone.  It is for acquired tastes only.  Indeed we were put off by the across-the-board profanity on the part of all the characters at first (after awhile we got used to it, denatured I suppose, or else maybe as the series goes on the characters swear less and less), it doesn't seem so much naturalistic as it does the producers just deciding to show you how much foul language they could get away with on cable on TV.  Thus the leading lady, in particular, young Ellen Muth, is saddled with some of the most gamy dialogue I've heard outside of the work of Pierre Guyotat.

But outside of that, the show really grows on you.  Muth is so odd you can't take your eyes off of her, sometimes she looks bruised as though she'd been beaten up, it's hard to figure out her age, but when they dress her up and make her up right, she looks like a cross between Sandra Dee and Brigitte Bardot.  Her mother, the admirable Cynthia Stevenson, is stuck with a two-note role that sometimes seems arbitrarily laced into the action of the various episodes, because as the show progresses, out attention drifts away from the grief of the Lass family and into the other areas of George's life.

Did anyone think the show is paying a kind of muted homage to the Glass family of J D Salinger?  Remember when George got fingered by the Reapers, and the name on her post it note was: "G.LASS"?  It's funny how her father, Clancy the professor, on his office door the plaque says, "C.LASS"!

But all in all we love the show.

I rarely follow tv series. Much of what is shown on tv nowadays doesn't really connect with me. "Dead Like Me" is an exception. This show is clever, funny, addictive...........and it also makes you think. Beautifully acted, nicely shot with vivid colors, this show is a must for anyone who just gets tired of all those court drama/investigation/cop series that are invading our tv screens. Not since "Six Feet Under" have I been that addicted and enthustiastic about a tv show. This DVD set presents the episodes with the best image quality and sound one could've hoped for. Not too many extras...but who cares when the show is THAT good ?

Dead Like Me is a witty, hysterical, and touching look at life, death, and what might come in between. The characters are all seperate entities, each with their own flaws and strengths. The principle character, George (played by Ellen Muth) dies via a toilet seat that falls out of space from the Russian space station. However, instead of passing into heaven as most dead people do, she becomes a grim reaper who joins a group of reapers assigned to violent deaths (murders, suicides, etc.).

The show uses her 'job' as a jumping off point to explore some darker themes. A lovers death driving a man to suicide, for example. It also hits on more mundane facts of life, like George looking for a day job to support her self. Reapers gotta eat too, you know.

The best part about the show is that it never loses its sense of humor, even in the darkest of moments. It's very refreshing to see a show that can handle both humor and drama. Do yourself a favor and buy this DVD set!

Good show for making me think.  I like the grim humor: dark but not depressing.  I don't get Showtime, so it looks like I have to buy the DVD set. Basically, George does like many people do in a new situation:  adjust by testing the limits of the rules.  A worthwhile show.  The audio and visual quality are very good.  I definitely like the widescreen picture.  There is some occasional swearing. Sex and violence is about the same as you would see on primetime tv.  An episode guide, just for a reminder of what happened this season:

1. Pilot (2 hours):  A young woman discovers that she has been assigned a job in the afterlife as a Reaper.

2. Dead Girl Walking:  George finds that shirking her duties has consequences for the souls.

3. Curious George:  George has trouble letting go of the past.

4. Reapercussions:  George learns a lesson when she tries to spare a soul.

5. Reaping Havoc:  A new friend jumps to the other side.

6. My Room:  George gets a new roommate after losing her friend.

7. Reaper Madness:  George has an affair with a living schizophrenic who can see her.

8. A Cook:  George brings home a dog.  Rube gets a job as a cook.

9. Sunday Mornings:  Mason falls for a girl he rescues from a rape.  The girl has a crush on George's father.

10. Business Unfinished:  The ghost of a rich lady is the target of a money-making scheme.

11. The Bicycle Thief :  George wants to buy a bicycle and leaves Happy Time for a higher paying job.

12. Nighthawks:  The Reapers have their annual evaluations, which consist of clips from previous shows shown with each reaper's self-evaluation.

13. Vacation:  The Reapers take the day off.

14. Rest in Peace:  George wants her job at Happy Time back.

This is a wonderful show. It's funny, it's great to watch, and it's just such a cool concept. Gives a new perspective on life and death. George is a really believable character. She's easy to relate to. She can't really grasp the reaper thing at first, she has a hard time leaving her family, and doesn't always do the right thing. She's a really great character and makes the show seem very real. The others aren't nearly as complex as her, but in each episode we see the characters develop. When Daisy is first introduced, she seems really bubbley, (...)happy and a stereotypical blonde. But then we see more in depth and that she is sad and real in later episodes. Same with Roxy, who at first seems sort of cold and uncaring about anything. But as the show develops, how she saved the one guy who she liked, and how she felt bad about her death, she gets a little more life. All of them do. Just like real people. At first people seem really one dimensional, but everybody has problems and emotions that take some time to notice. I love the character development in this show.

 Overall, Dead Like Me is really well-acted, funny and real. It's unlike a lot of television these days and it's refreshing. There's not a lot of romance, there's just people. The undead seem more like real people than most of the people on television. It's a good show, one of the best I've seen.

 One star was taken off because this isn't a flawless show. The special effects are really bad, and some of the things that happen are too out there and just not believable. I don't like the home stuff with the Lass family all that well. The mom is very annoying, Clancy is okay and Reggie is a bit too weird that she's not really that believable anymore. Also Delores is too far out there to believe. Things like George's going away party at work and the way a lot of the people die seem too far-fetched for me. Also when George died, she acted like a real person would. Really confused and angry and then just kind of pissed off. None of the other people who die seem to care that much. They just think "Hey I'm dead, going to the afterlife now. Cool." And characters just seem to disappear, as well as things that happen, from episode to episode. Like what happened to Charlotte? It loses some of the magic of the show, I think. But it's still, besides Scrubs and Freaks and Geeks, probably one of my favorite shows of all time.

I recently purchased the DVD set for this show because I do not subscribe to Showtime. I finished watching all 14 episodes in 1 weekend and I have to say, the show was better than I ever expected! This cant even be compared to Six Feet Under because Dead Like Me on a completely different level! If you don't want to wait until June 2005 to see the second season on DVD, you'll have to subscribe to Showtime. It will be well worth the extra money.

Any fears I had about "Dead Like Me" being nothing more than a way for Showtime to cash in on the success and brilliance of HBO's extraordinary "Six Feet Under" series were quickly laid to rest (pun intended) when I sunk my teeth into this well-acted, entertaining and quirky series. "Dead Like Me" proposes that souls not evil enough for hell or evolved enough for heaven become employed as Grim Reapers in the afterlife, put to work extracting the souls from people right before their moment of death, and then guiding them into their personal afterlife (which usually ingeniously takes the form of whatever they imagine bliss to be). The Reapers themselves are all deeply flawed, and yet likeable, characters who have passed away at different points in time, and who have to pay their karmic debt by doing the job until the Almighty judges that they've "met their quota". The main character, George, played with loads of charm and poise by the young Ellen Muth, is a rebellious, lazy teenager who, despite the rules against it, still watches over her mourning, dysfunctional family. The great Mandy Patinkin plays the Grim Reaper "manager" Rube, and also serves as father figure and mentor to George, goofy British hoodlum Mason, angry meter maid Roxy (the sexy and talented Jasmine Guy) and vain, self-absorbed Daisy. Although the emphasis is mostly on quirky comedy, the series also does a good job of exploring life's (and death's) bigger questions. Overall, a very worthwhile series.

This is one of my favorite shows of the past few years.  In fact, I don't think I have been this satisfied with watching a new show in the past few years! The show is well written, original (ok death is a common theme on a few new shows, but they don't do it like this!), and the supporting cast is fantastic!!! I keep thinking that this character or that character is a favorite, but then remember other aspects of another character I like too.  Even the smaller characters like Crystal, the happy time receptionist,  or the waitresses at Der Waffle Hous.  Kind of reminds me somewhat of the show Northern Exposure, but with a black twist.  I haven't seen the DVD, just have watched the show, but I can recomend this show to anyone, and I have!

I first learned of This series recently when watching episodes 13 and 14 on showtime. Prior to the other day I've never heard of or have seen this program. I was completely enthralled by the beautiful characterization and the quirky black humor that filled this series. I imediately bought the DVD boxset and have spent most of today watching the series from beginning to end.

 This series offers a lot of comic relief, as well as a very large dose of cynicism. Ellen Muth is absolutely perfect in the role of George. Her narration of the series brings her thoughts closer to us, and offers a very intimate perspective of her life with her fellow reapers. Manny Patimkin is perfect in his role as the reaper foreman. I'm a little sad to see Gayheart leave after a few episodes, but am also happy they picked Laura Harris (who I first saw in her role in "faculty") to replace her.

 I enjoy a series that has colorful characters down to the secondary actors, such as george/milly's happy time coworkers. It's a different perspective on death, and on life. Following George's family through many of the episodes allows us a glimpse into a fully realized world that doesn't cease to enthrall us.

 I'm looking forward to season 2 starting this sunday (july 25th at 10pm, 2004). I reccomend this DVD set whole-heartedly. not only is it a great value at under $42, it's in a very attractive box with tons of artwork and extras included in every aspect of this item. I'd reccomend this just for the fact of getting close-ups of the various cast members, which fill the menues and special features sections of the DVD.

Originally I tuned into DLM because it was summer and there was nothing else on, and in the beginning it was just that: a pretty decent show for the summer.  However, as the season progressed I thought that the characters were fleshed out better (you learn more about the supporting cast's past) and there was even a storyline (rather than each episode being independent).
Anyways, why four stars? Because it's entertaining, full of dry humor and the characters are human and imperfect...which makes it better then 95% of the shows out there.

I don't have Showtime (or cable for that matter), but after having great luck with The Sopranos I decided to give this series a spin. I don't know why, but it is very addicting! I watched all 14 episodes in about 3 or 4 days. Very original ideas, a very good cast that you grow attached too, and some touching moments as well all add up to good fun.
The series is not perfect but I found myself forgiving any faults because the good far outweighs the bad. The only disappointments I had were: the special features are lacking, and one of the episodes (i think it is 12) is practically nothing but flashbacks, so if you watch this series in a matter of days like I did (and you will want to) then you will spend most of the time watching this episode either bored or fast forwarding - I don't think this was necessary at all for a show in its first season - but even allowing for these slight negatives I give Dead Like Me 5 stars!

I bought this set on a whim.... I don't have Showtime, but I remembered seeing a clip on the filming of the pilot on one of those entertainment TV shows. I am SO glad that I did!!!
This is a truly great show! In an age where most TV shows are "reality" based or just another tired, been-there-done-that premise, this one grabs hold and sucks you in. The dialogue snaps and sizzles; making me wish that I could have come up with half of those lines.  Each episode's story lines whips back and forth through both comedic and dramatic scences; never dwelling too long on the the sad aspects of death (But just enough to give the show some substance).
The charaters are exceptional. Ellen Muth plays the new reaper; most of the show is seen through her eyes as she learns the rules of her strange new existence, and trying to reconcile herself with those she left behind. Mandy Patinkin plays her boss, Rube. He is an excellent Antagonist for George (Muth). In fact, he comes off as a gruff father-figure for George. Rounding out the cast is Jasmine Guy (Remember her from "A Different World"? You won't here), a tough talking reaper who has a day job working as a Meter-Maid; Callum Blue, a "Trainspotting"-esque reaper; Rebecca Gayheart, the beauty queen reaper; Cynthia Stevenson, George's bitter mother and Britt McKillip, as George's weird younger sister. While there are several other recurring characters, they don't seem to be as important as the one I mentioned.
I recommend this show to any one who enjoys the quirky and unusual, as well as fans of "Tru Calling", "Buffy the Vampire Slayer", "Joan of Arcadia", "X-Files" and "Twin Peaks".
I just wish this show was on regular TV. Now I'll have to wait for season 2 to come out on DVD. Looks like it will be a loooong wait.

Ellen Muth is extremely hot by the way. but about the show. i give it a 5, humor , sadness. the show jsut beings me to a very happy place. its almost my next buffy. it feels very good to watch that show. its up there with mscl. reminds me of the early  90's with those shows on nick at night. pete and pete, and daria, and all that. good times. i recommend dlm to anyone and everyone, and im usually not this generous. hope this hellped.

I couldn't wait to get a hold of this DVD set. And I have to tell you, I was not disappointed...
The deleted scenes are wonderful but I wish they had not left them out of the original airing.
- We finally get to see the Post-it that brought George over to the dark side.
- Who knew that the DMV also issues Reaper licenses.
- The men at Happy Times have a very, very, VERY stange and disgusting secret.
While some of the clips are several minutes long, a few of them are only a couple of seconds which makes it hard to figure out exactly what you are watching.
I do wish they had an option that would allow you to insert the deleted clips back into the original airings so you could watch it straight through, but overall they are well worth it.
There are about 15 pictures that you can scroll through along with audio commentary and "The Music of DLM" Featurette.
Overall, it is a great buy and you won't be disappointed...

"Dead Like Me" proves that cynicism, humor, depth, and even compassion can not only co-exist on a single television series, they can actually flourish together. With sharp and witty writing and directing, "Dead Like Me" explores the bizarre world of our working-class grim reapers, the good folks charged with escorting human souls to the afterlife.  As the second-lowest level group of bureaucrats in the afterlife system (best not to ask about the lowest), grim reapers must trudge along "popping" the souls of the soon-to-be-departed before they meet their grisly (and, dare I say, often hilarious) ends. And they must also survive, and pay rent, in the living world.
The chief protagonist on the series is George (a.k.a. Georgia), a recently deceased, uber-cynical, 18 year old who just can't seem to resist rebelling against the whole "death" system. Her fellow reapers include an unapologetically opportunistic drug-smuggler, a meter-maid who does a lot more than write parking tickets, a happy-go-lucky pragmatist who has developed a truly macabre taste in photography, and an actress whose resume is surprisingly out of date. And then, of course, there is Rube.
Rube is the would-be foreman of this somewhat strange assemblage of reapers. He is also, arguably, the most sympathetic, complex, and mysterious character on the show-thanks in no small part to the superb acting of Mandy Patinkin. As with the other characters on the show, no amount of space here can really hint at the depth alloted to Rube by the writers and directors of "Dead Like Me" or the skill with which Patinkin explores that depth. Suffice it to say that Rube plays a lot more like a real person (or real undead person) than any mere television contrivance. Rube is more alive as a dead man than any television character from the living world.
The very essence of "Dead Like Me" is, in fact, its willingness to explore not only the bizarre world of the reapers, but also the lives and personalities of the reapers themselves. Undead life has had (and continues to have) some pretty strange effects on these formerly-living reapers, and watching their individual responses to the problems of their bizarre occupation provides much of the humor of the show.
And, not to leave out the living world, the creative minds behind "Dead Like Me," also frequently turn their attention to living characters on the show, from the "soon to be referred to the past tense" reaper clients to the families they leave behind (most notably George's grieving family). Just about any character is subject to being fleshed-out on this show (even dogs and frogs). A minor character named Angus Cook makes a more memorable impression in one epsiode of "Dead Like Me" (appropriately titled "A. Cook") than most TV series regulars will make in an entire season.
Some have compared "Dead Like Me" with shows like "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" and similar, more pedestrian, fare. But about the only thing Buffy and George have in common is youth and blonde hair. And the only thing the reapers have in common with television vampires is that they've both been around a while. Of course, one of the problems with television vampires is that they never seem to *realize* they've been around a while. They are also generally kind enough to join up with either the "good guys" or "bad guys" teams of the Buffyverse and its ilk, teams which don't exist in the universe of "Dead Like Me."
But you might want to visit the universe of "Dead Like Me" for yourself, and form your own impressions. Just don't stay too long. You might end up with a post-it note and a new job.

In the best traditions of Cult television, DLM uses a fantasy storyline to explore relationships and the way people live their lives. In the case of the reapers, the way that they live their undead lives.

George, the disaffected teenager begins to understand and appreciate things in ways that she never did in her life before becoming a reaper. Although she is the anchor-woman to the storyline, the strength of the programme is in the character development of ALL the cast. In just 14 episodes you feel an emotional attachment to the characters that you'd never get by watching a year of your favourite soap.
Buffy fans should love this series. It has darker humour than Buffy with some wonderfully adult language and one-liners but has that same mix of humour and deep intensity within the space of a couple of seconds.
Slapstick reaping scenes add to the entertainment but it's real strength is in the deeply moving interraction between the characters as they get through their lives- some living, some undead. Superbly written you are hanging on every word.
Very rarely do I buy a DVD and even rarer to buy a DVD from across the Atlantic that probably won't play too well in my machine. But this is one that I'm not going to miss.

Not only the deaf need subtitles.
There's a lot of people who live in a no-english speaking country where this series will NEVER show up, that also need them. Sometimes you can get lost trying to follow the speaking (due to talking speed or accent), but if you can read is much easier.
The series itself is great. I found it in the internet and I had a lot of laughs with it.

Nothing to say about the show, it rocks !!!!
But i always wonder why those DVD set never contain any Subtitles. May be useless for you, but when you're deaf... It's a shame...

Clearly the Best original show of last year.  The director borrowed heavily from Piers Anthony series The Incarnation of Immortality.  This is a 7 book set.  Read the first book too
"On a Pale Horse".
Anyway, clearly well written and well acted.
Kudos

I watched the original version with french subtitles on french TV this year and whoaaa !!! this first season rocks !! Great teleplay, great actors and great directing, I can wait for the second season ..... and THE DVD SET !!

I haven't watched a whole lot of TV within the last five years.  I worked nights.  I had no real desire to keep an eye on all the shows I would miss.  A friend told me to watch this one and now I can't stop.  This is brilliantly written and acted.  I can't wait for the second season, and I'm rewatching this one.

This is a great show, better than just about anything on American television.  The series has great writing, great directing, great acting, and great music.  Each episode is at once funny, intelligent, warm, caring, and contemplative.  How many other shows can you point to that manage to cram that much into each 50 minutes?  Get this and then watch season two on Showtime!
One of my personal favorites.
yes this is a very good tv show
One of my all time favorite shows. Was only on for I believe 2 seasons. Great premise, stories and writing.
love this quirky series with a dry witty humor
No CC for the hearing impaired.

I really wish amazon wouldn't pressure me for written reviews on things I've rated five stars; I OBVIOUSLY LOVE IT, WHAT MORE DO THEY NEED TO KNOW?
Nicely packaged (used but fair condition) dvd season, nothing extravagant. I likevthe show so I bought it.

Here's a tip in case anyone reads these, though. If a dvd is scratchy and skips or freezes, try polishing it with wax furniture polish like pledge. The wax fills in the sctatches clearly enough for the laser to read the disc. You're welcome!
I just wish Amazon would add this to Prime so I could watch it again with my husband.

Great, oddball series for those who like dark humor & sometimes twisted wit. Mandy Patinkin is (as always) wonderful as the lead undead civil servant Reuben. Ellen Muth is a quirky actress herself, which makes her perfect as the rather gormless young woman who's totally lacking in drive (or a clue as to what to do with her life). Her inability to get going in life hits a major snag when she is killed when a piece of the toilet from a space station flattens her.*
The writing in this series is great, with non-cardboard characters that you can develop a real liking for while being entertained by the wry & satiric wit.

*ok, it's not a toilet piece that'd ever actually be on a space station --for space purists-- but roll with it.
I love this show!! Great show to watch to get me away from "Real Life". I just recently moved and can't find this dvd set :( So I will be definitely be reordering. Great seller, and great show.
Great Series!
